subject: VM resize: skip ssh work for VMs w/o local disks
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-04 14:26:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/cad29e345c20fe30727b399603a495811e93ba53', 'message': 'VM resize: skip ssh work for VMs w/o local disks

VM resizing action is a bit fragile because of its dependency on
nova-compute user being able to freely ssh/scp among compute hosts.
Resize will fail under two scnearios:
- when SSH keys are not set up properly
- when SSH dest must be a full hostname (say kerberos is used for
  authentication) - currently only remote IPs are used for ssh/scp.

Instead of fully fixing this problem, this commit tries to mitigate
the reliance on ssh/scp in a legitimate scenario in which no ssh/scp
interactions are needed -- when a resized VM has no local disk,
thus disk_info being an empty list. In this scenario, the VM in
question only has volumes attached, which voids the need of copying
disk images around.

commit_message:
VM resize: skip ssh work for VMs w/o local disks

Closes-bug: 1303203

VM resizing action is a bit fragile because of its dependency on
nova-compute user being able to freely ssh/scp among compute hosts.
Resize will fail under two scnearios:
- when SSH keys are not set up properly
- when SSH dest must be a full hostname (say kerberos is used for
  authentication) - currently only remote IPs are used for ssh/scp.

Instead of fully fixing this problem, this commit tries to mitigate
the reliance on ssh/scp in a legitimate scenario in which no ssh/scp
interactions are needed -- when a resized VM has no local disk,
thus disk_info being an empty list. In this scenario, the VM in
question only has volumes attached, which voids the need of copying
disk images around.

One existing test case is modified to avoid triggering the new code. One
test case is added to ensure the new code is properly triggered when VM
has no local disk.

Change-Id: I0a1da3846e5e291d1db422e5d2f67c9a38d1ab8c

deleted_lines: shared_storage = self._is_storage_shared_with(dest, inst_base) # try to create the directory on the remote compute node # if this fails we pass the exception up the stack so we can catch # failures here earlier if not shared_storage: utils.execute('ssh', dest, 'mkdir', '-p', inst_base)

commit_message:
Introduce Hitachi Block Storage Driver v2

Changes from v1
 - Fix flake8 issues of all files to pass pep8 automated test.
 - Mock get_process_lock() out to avoid access to /var/lock
   while running tests.
 - Move _VOLUME and test_snapshot into test case classes. (Eric's comment)
 - Remove vim modelines of files in the directory of
   cinder/volume/drivers/hitachi. (Eric's comment)
 - Add a hitachi_debug_file option to hitachi_common.py.
   And, while running tests, change it to /dev/null to avoid access
   to /var/log. (Eric's comment)
 - Remove importing gettext and calling gettext.install() from files
   in the directory of cinder/volume/drivers/hitachi. (Eric's comment)
 - Set blocksize and pass it to copy_volume in hitachi_basiclib.py
   to fix failure of a gate-cinder-pylint test.
 - Remove unneeded argument of _terminate_connection in hitachi_iscsi.py
   to fix failure of a gate-cinder-pylint test.

   Introduce Hitachi Block Storage Driver for Hitachi VSP, HUS-VM
   and HUS arrays with Fibre Channel and iSCSI.

    This will support all features required in Icehouse:
    * Volume Create/Delete
    * Volume Attach/Detach
    * Snapshot Create/Delete
    * Create Volume from Snapshot
    * Copy Image to Volume
    * Copy Volume to Image
    * Clone Volume
    * Extend Volume

Implements: blueprint hitachi-block-storage-driver

Change-Id: Ifc62529427e2749ef991c46fe9fbaf308cb2b759
Signed-off-by: Seiji Aguchi <seiji.aguchi.tr@hitachi.com>

commit_message:
Allows HARD_REBOOT to instances in the state REBOOTING_HARD

* Removes the check for reboot_type "hard" and state "REBOOTING_HARD" that raises exception
  and allows hard reboot to happen in the state REBOOTING_HARD.

Change-Id: I65c5bd5527909b623f281a74ee2034cab8d5a440
Closes-Bug: #1290746

commit_message:
Return proper exception on PolicyNotAuthorized

In the current code, HTTPNotFound is returned when a policy
does not allow a tenant to perform an operation. This could
be misleading. This patch returns the proper exception.

Closes-Bug: #1296953
Change-Id: I4aa23e304ed1831999904023066b4f45cce398cc

commit_message:
Firewall as a Service (FWaaS)  Service Insertion

This implements Fwaas service insertion
into neutron. The insertion information
is saved in service-context.

blueprint fwaas-service-insertion
blueprint neutron-services-insertion-chaining-steering

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ic481d180a9877af529c13ff4ec54cd962b6f1518
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/99/62599/66 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # Copyright (c) 2012 OpenStack Foundation. # All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from neutron.api import extensions from neutron.api.v2 import attributes from neutron.common import exceptions as qexception # Service Context Exceptions class ServiceContextNotFound(qexception.NotFound): message = _("Service Context %(service_context_id) could not be found.") class NetworkContextNotFound(qexception.NotFound): message = _("Network Context %(service_context_id) could not be found.") class SubnetContextNotFound(qexception.NotFound): message = _("Subnet Context %(service_context_id) could not be found.") class PortContextNotFound(qexception.NotFound): message = _("Port Context %(service_context_id) could not be found.") class RouterContextNotFound(qexception.NotFound): message = _("Router Context %(service_context_id) could not be found.") # The list of networks where service needs to be inserted SI_CONTEXT_NETWORKS = 'service_context:networks' # The list of subnets where service needs to be inserted SI_CONTEXT_SUBNETS = 'service_context:subnets' # The list of neutron ports where service needs to be inserted SI_CONTEXT_PORTS = 'service_context:ports' # The list of routers where service needs to be inserted SI_CONTEXT_ROUTERS = 'service_context:routers' EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0 = { 'firewalls': { SI_CONTEXT_NETWORKS: {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'default': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'validate': {'type:uuid_list': None}, 'is_visible': True}, SI_CONTEXT_SUBNETS: {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'default': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'validate': {'type:uuid_list': None}, 'is_visible': True}, SI_CONTEXT_PORTS: {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'default': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'validate': {'type:uuid_list': None}, 'is_visible': True}, SI_CONTEXT_ROUTERS: {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True, 'default': attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, 'validate': {'type:uuid_list': None}, 'is_visible': True}, } } class Servicecontext(extensions.ExtensionDescriptor): """Extension class supporting service insertion context. This class is used by neutron's extension framework to make metadata about the service insertion context to be used by services such as Firewall, Vpn etc. """ @classmethod def get_name(cls): return "Service Insertion Context" @classmethod def get_alias(cls): return "servicecontext" @classmethod def get_description(cls): return "Expose point of insertion to services such as Firewall" @classmethod def get_namespace(cls): return "http://docs.openstack.org/ext/binding/api/v1.0" @classmethod def get_updated(cls): return "2013-12-03T10:00:00-00:00" def get_extended_resources(self, version): if version == "2.0": return EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES_2_0 else: return {}

subject: Add httmock to test-requirements.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-21 03:39:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/040da9fb16a41521fc9620244f1290b7a37e6fb9', 'message': 'Update requests to 2.10 and add httmock to tests

In testing REST client code in Neutron, I was seeing the wrong
exception generated, when there was an HTTP timeout on request.
Googled and found that 2.1.0 resolves the issue (and verified
that it did).

To make unit tests easier, would like to include httmock package
from PyPI. This is a mocking library for the requests package
and makes tests much simpler.

commit_message:
Add httmock to test-requirements.

    To make unit tests easier, would like to include httmock package
    from PyPI. This is a mocking library for the requests package
    and makes tests much simpler. This is an Apache 2.0 licensed
    package in PyPI.

Change-Id: I42df522eb841f0798f742e5ff375fcd94908f93d
Partial-Bug: 1282855

commit_message:
Sync rpc modules from oslo-incubator

The main reason for sync is to get the following oslo-rpc fixes in
Ceilometer:

* Ia148baa6e1ec632789ac3621c85173c2c16f3918 (fixed HA failover, Qpid part)
* I67923cb024bbd143edc8edccf35b9b400df31eb3 (fixed HA failover, RabbitMQ part)

Change-Id: I210e24bdf132acdd3340b30aa2c8ac8402b23099
Closes-Bug: 1261631

commit_message:
Changes in openstack-common related code

1. Module 'apiclient' installation from oslo installs
   all dependent modules hence we should get rid of
   all other modules mentioned in openstack-common.conf

2. Sync of oslo common code.

Change be81d6b: Cleanup unused log related code
Change 8575d87: Removed copyright from empty files
Change bbaf317: Use encode() instead of strutils.safe_encode() in fake_client
Change 00337e0: Fix E501 in individual openstack projects
Change ec6d900: Add support for locales missing from babel
Change fc1843b: Make Message keep string interpolation argsa
Change 221c37d: Allow the Message class to have non-English default locales
Change 0e1af5b: Implementation of translation log handler
Change 2cfc1a7: Translation Message improvements
Change 3017e1d: Use hacking import_exceptions for gettextutils._
Change 8710dba: Add method quote_plus in module py3kcompat.urlutils
Change 2a7b1af: Fix a bug in safe_encode where it returns a bytes object in py3

Change-Id: Ibcf6a47e926eba762b4f8ad44fa418a01560c978

commit_message:
Create utils module for processing task results

Here we create a special rally.benchmark.processing.utils module for
computing different functions on the benchmark data.

The @computes decorator implemented there allows one to specify in human language
what the functions are computing (this is used then while drawing the resulting tables).

The @omit_failures decorator allows to easily specify whether the function needs all the
single run runtimes or only those which are not None (e.g. successfully measured).

We also start here the refactoring of the code in rally.cmd.task.TaskCommand.detailed()
to make this module more readable. This patch introduces changes to the process of
drawing the main results table, while tables for atomic actions and scenario specific
results are to be rewritten in future patches.

Change-Id: I64d83e3bb2a95b6cb7d4f535aec742329574432d

added_lines: from rally.benchmark.processing import utils task_aggregated_info = utils.aggregated_info(result["data"]["raw"]) atomic_actions_table = prettytable.PrettyTable( task_aggregated_info["atomic_actions"]["keys"]) for row in task_aggregated_info["atomic_actions"]["data"]: atomic_actions_table.add_row(row) print(atomic_actions_table) print() result_table = prettytable.PrettyTable( task_aggregated_info["result"]["keys"]) for row in task_aggregated_info["result"]["data"]: result_table.add_row(row) print(result_table) raw = result["data"]["raw"] utils.percentile(values, 0.90), utils.percentile(values, 0.95)]
deleted_lines: import collectionsimport math def _print_atomic_actions_time(raw): atime_merged = [] for r in raw: if 'atomic_actions_time' in r: for a in r['atomic_actions_time']: atime_merged.append(a) times_by_action = collections.defaultdict(list) for at in atime_merged: times_by_action[at['action']].append(at['duration']) if times_by_action: atomic_action_table = prettytable.PrettyTable( ['action', 'count', 'max (sec)', 'avg (sec)', 'min (sec)', '90 percentile', '95 percentile']) for k, v in times_by_action.iteritems(): atomic_action_table.add_row([k, len(v), max(v), sum(v) / len(v), min(v), percentile(v, 0.90), percentile(v, 0.95)]) print(atomic_action_table) print() _print_atomic_actions_time(result["data"]["raw"]) raw = result["data"]["raw"] times = map(lambda x: x['time'], filter(lambda r: not r['error'], raw)) table = prettytable.PrettyTable(["max (sec)", "avg (sec)", "min (sec)", "90 pecentile", "95 percentile", "success/total", "total times"]) if times: table.add_row([max(times), sum(times) / len(times), min(times), percentile(times, 0.90), percentile(times, 0.95), float(len(times)) / len(raw), len(raw)]) else: table.add_row(['n/a', 'n/a', 'n/a', 'n/a', 'n/a', 0, len(raw)]) print(table) percentile(values, 0.90), percentile(values, 0.95)] def percentile(N, percent): """Find the percentile of a list of values. @parameter N - is a list of values. @parameter percent - a float value from 0.0 to 1.0. @return - the percentile of the values """ if not N: return None N.sort() k = (len(N) - 1) * percent f = math.floor(k) c = math.ceil(k) if f == c: return N[int(k)] d0 = N[int(f)] * (c - k) d1 = N[int(c)] * (k - f) return (d0 + d1)

commit_message:
Use built-in print() instead of print statement

In python 3 print statement is not supported, so we should use
only print() functions.

Fixes bug 1226943

Change-Id: If5d2e6159aa85b0be267ab66d3d648baec376a75

subject: cinder client should retry with Retry-After value
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-25 07:54:37.000000000', 'files': ['cinderclient/tests/test_http.py', 'cinderclient/client.py', 'cinderclient/exceptions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient/commit/9693d0d1c40ab26e735ee2d5404ee5c15b4c69ee', 'message': 'cinder client should retry with Retry-After value

If a request fails but the response contains a "Retry-After",
the cinder client should wait the amount of time and then retry

Cinder client should report a warning to user and continue with retry,
so that user can cancel the operation if not interested in retry

The value in "Retry-After" header will be in seconds or GMT value,
client should handle both the cases

How many times client should retry will be controlled by user through
"--retries" argument to cinder api
example, cinder --retries 3 availability-zone-list
If request was not sucessful within the retries, client should raise
the exception

Added test case "test_rate_limit_overlimit_exception" in which client
raises the exception when request was not succesful within the retries
after wainting for "Retry-After" time

Added test case "test_rate_limit" in which client succesfully retries
the request after wainting for "Retry-After" time

Present limitation - client will wait with the seconds given
by the server.Now a warning message will be reported to the user
with this waiting time, user can cancel the retry if he thinks that
this will be huge time.

In future implementation, user can set max wait time for "Retry-After"
as a command line option or a configuration option. Then client should
retry only if the "retry-After" value is less than what the user has set

Partial-Bug: #1263069

Change-Id: I286f2a70c09c39a274174dce0b031b67ddb42f9e
'}]
commit_message:
cinder client should retry with Retry-After value

If a request fails but the response contains a "Retry-After",
the cinder client should wait the amount of time and then retry

Cinder client should report a warning to user and continue with retry,
so that user can cancel the operation if not interested in retry

The value in "Retry-After" header will be in seconds or GMT value,
client should handle both the cases

How many times client should retry will be controlled by user through
"--retries" argument to cinder api
example, cinder --retries 3 availability-zone-list
If request was not sucessful within the retries, client should raise
the exception

Added test case "test_rate_limit_overlimit_exception" in which client
raises the exception when request was not succesful within the retries
after wainting for "Retry-After" time

Added test case "test_rate_limit" in which client succesfully retries
the request after wainting for "Retry-After" time

Present limitation - client will wait with the seconds given
by the server.Now a warning message will be reported to the user
with this waiting time, user can cancel the retry if he thinks that
this will be huge time.

In future implementation, user can set max wait time for "Retry-After"
as a command line option or a configuration option. Then client should
retry only if the "retry-After" value is less than what the user has set

Partial-Bug: #1263069

Change-Id: I286f2a70c09c39a274174dce0b031b67ddb42f9e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/13/76113/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import datetime def __init__(self, code, message=None, details=None, request_id=None, response=None): retry_after = 0 def __init__(self, code, message=None, details=None, request_id=None, response=None): super(OverLimit, self).__init__(code, message=message, details=details, request_id=request_id, response=response) self._get_rate_limit(response) def _get_rate_limit(self, resp): if resp.headers: if resp.headers.get('Retry-After'): utc_now = datetime.datetime.utcnow() value = resp.headers.get('Retry-After') # ValueError will be raised by strptime, # if Retry-After Value is not in HTTP-date format try: value = datetime.datetime.strptime( value, '%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S %Z') except ValueError: self.retry_after = float(value) else: if(value > utc_now): self.retry_after = ((value - utc_now).seconds) request_id=request_id, response=response) else: return cls(code=response.status_code, request_id=request_id, response=response)
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, code, message=None, details=None, request_id=None): request_id=request_id) else: return cls(code=response.status_code, request_id=request_id)

commit_message:
SPBM support for VMware storage backend

The VMware storage backend should be able to place the images
based on storage policies.
Currently, it is only possible to select one datastore to place
the images.
With this patch, the user can provide a storage policy defined
in vCenter server instead of specifying directly a datastore.

Among the subset of datastores matching the policy, the datastore
with most free space and accessible will be selected.

If the policy provided is not found in VC or no matching datastore
if found, the datastore specified in the configuration will be used.

SPBM should be used with vCenter server 5.5+.

More information about SPBM: http://goo.gl/GR2o6U

Implements bp storage-policies-vmware-store

Change-Id: I9f0b3f116bf69fe16681ad36a3d2afaafa7c7f3f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/46/73746/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from glance.store.vmware import spbm_util from glance.store.vmware import vim_util spbm_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('spbm_wsdl_location', help=_('SPBM service WSDL file location URL. ' 'e.g. file:///opt/SDK/spbm/wsdl/spbmService.wsdl. ' 'Not setting this will disable storage policy based ' 'placement of images.')), cfg.StrOpt('spbm_policy', help=_('The SPBM policy. If pbm_wsdl_location is set, ' 'a SPBM policy needs to be specified. This policy ' 'will be used to select the datastore in which the ' 'images will be stored.')), ] CONF.register_opts(spbm_opts)def _select_datastores_matching_storage_policy(session, datastores, storage_policy): """Get datastores matching the given storage policy. :param datastores: the list of datastores in the datacenter :param storage_policy: the storage policy name :return the list of datastores conforming to the given storage policy """ spbm = session._spbm profile_id = spbm_util.retrieve_profile_id(session, storage_policy) if profile_id: ds_morefs = [oc.obj for oc in datastores.objects] hubs = spbm_util.convert_datastores_to_hubs( spbm.client.factory, ds_morefs) matching_hubs = spbm_util.filter_matching_hubs(session, hubs, profile_id) if matching_hubs: matching_ds = spbm_util.convert_hubs_to_datastores(matching_hubs, ds_morefs) object_contents = [oc for oc in datastores.objects if oc.obj in matching_ds] datastores.objects = object_contents return datastores LOG.debug(_("Unable to retrieve storage policy with name %s"), storage_policy) def _select_datastore(session, datastores): """Select the datastore with most free space among accessible datastores :param datastores: a list of datastores :return the name of the datastore with most free space and accessible """ ds_morefs = [oc.obj for oc in datastores.objects] max_free_space = 0 for ds in ds_morefs: props = session.invoke_api(vim_util, "get_object_properties", session.vim, ds, ["name", "summary.accessible", "summary.freeSpace"]) prop = props[0] if prop.propSet[1].val is False: continue elif prop.propSet[2].val > max_free_space: selected_ds = prop.propSet[0].val max_free_space = prop.propSet[2].val return selected_ds self.spbm_wsdl = CONF.spbm_wsdl_location self.spbm_policy = CONF.spbm_policy self.task_poll_interval, spbm_wsdl=self.spbm_wsdl) # check if SPBM is configured self._storage_policy_enabled = False if self.spbm_wsdl and self.spbm_policy: if not spbm_util.retrieve_profile_id(self._session, self.spbm_policy): reason = _("The configured SPBM policy '%s' is not " "defined on vCenter Server.") % self.spbm_policy LOG.info(_("Successfully verified existence of " "spbm_policy: %s"), self.spbm_policy) self._storage_policy_enabled = True if self._storage_policy_enabled: # select datastore in the storage policy datastores = self._session.invoke_api( vim_util, "get_objects", self._session.vim, "Datastore") matching_ds = _select_datastores_matching_storage_policy( self._session, datastores, self.spbm_policy) self.datastore_name = _select_datastore(self._session, matching_ds) if self.datastore_name is None: msg = (_("Could not find a datastore matching the storage " "policy %(policy)") % {'policy': self.spbm_policy}) LOG.warn(msg) self._storage_policy_enabled = False if not self._storage_policy_enabled: self.datastore_name = self._option_get('vmware_datastore_name') global _datastore_info_valid if not _datastore_info_valid: search_index_moref = self._service_content.searchIndex inventory_path = ('%s/datastore/%s' % (self.datacenter_path, self.datastore_name)) ds_moref = self._session.invoke_api(self._session.vim, 'FindByInventoryPath', search_index_moref, inventoryPath= inventory_path) if ds_moref is None: reason = (_("Could not find datastore %(ds_name)s " "in datacenter %(dc_path)s") % {'ds_name': self.datastore_name, 'dc_path': self.datacenter_path}) raise exception.BadStoreConfiguration( store_name='vmware_datastore', reason=reason)
deleted_lines: self.task_poll_interval) self.datastore_name = self._option_get('vmware_datastore_name') global _datastore_info_valid if not _datastore_info_valid: search_index_moref = self._service_content.searchIndex inventory_path = ('%s/datastore/%s' % (self.datacenter_path, self.datastore_name)) ds_moref = self._session.invoke_api(self._session.vim, 'FindByInventoryPath', search_index_moref, inventoryPath=inventory_path) if ds_moref is None: reason = (_("Could not find datastore %(ds_name)s " "in datacenter %(dc_path)s") % {'ds_name': self.datastore_name, 'dc_path': self.datacenter_path}) ds_validated = True

commit_message:
Make block migration work with LVM backend

Change libvirt driver to not wrongly ignore lvm disks and to
return the correct disk type for lvm disks with correct size
so that migration destination can re-create the instance disks
in the right way.

Change-Id: I4a014f98f1a6627171334c038bb88a4eef70a55c
Closes-Bug: #1282643

revisions:

commit_message:
Add unit test for checking right order of sample list

 This commit checks descending order by timestamp of samples
 in api response

Change-Id: Iaddd70cc59bf1cbaa32fe261164ac9253cc0b59b
Related: bug #1294663
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/74/84674/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- encoding: utf-8 -*- # # Copyright  2014 Mirantis Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import datetime import logging import random import testscenarios from ceilometer.publisher import utils from ceilometer import sample from ceilometer.tests.api.v2 import FunctionalTest from ceilometer.tests import db as tests_db load_tests = testscenarios.load_tests_apply_scenarios LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class TestListSamples(FunctionalTest, tests_db.MixinTestsWithBackendScenarios): def test_list_samples_order(self): smp = sample.Sample( 'instance', 'cumulative', '', 1, 'user-id', 'project-id', 'resource-id', timestamp="", resource_metadata={'display_name': 'test-server', 'tag': 'self.sample'}, source='test_list_resources', ) desc_sorted_messages = [] for i in range(10): smp.timestamp = datetime.datetime( random.randint(2000, 2100), random.randint(1, 12), random.randint(1, 20), random.randint(0, 23), random.randint(0, 59), random.randint(0, 59)) msg = utils.meter_message_from_counter( smp, self.CONF.publisher.metering_secret, ) self.conn.record_metering_data(msg) desc_sorted_messages.insert(0, msg) data = self.get_json('/meters/instance') self.assertEqual(len(desc_sorted_messages), len(data)) prev_ts = datetime.datetime(2500, 1, 1, 1, 1) for smp in data: current_ts = datetime.datetime.strptime(smp['timestamp'], "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S") self.assertTrue((prev_ts - current_ts).total_seconds() >= 0)

subject: Adds flavor.id metric
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-24 00:00:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/71fbdcd34f1b32b121a21cda956ed938667d57c8', 'message': 'Adds flavor.id metric

Simple metric for tracking of flavor changes over time for a given instance.

Adds a pollster to update flavor on polling interval, and a notification that updates on create, delete, and resize to have accurate flavor data at any given point.

Adds tests for flavor id metric, and updates test notifications to also have the "instance_flavor_id" value.

Change-Id: I6d242330d088dc152b92e509265ececb8627dea2

commit_message:
Adds flavor.id metric

Simple metric for tracking of flavor changes over time for a given
instance.

Adds a pollster to update flavor on polling interval, and a
notification that updates on create, delete, and resize to have
accurate flavor data at any given point.

Adds tests for flavor id metric, and updates test notifications to
also have the "instance_flavor_id" value.

Metric added to docs.

Change-Id: I6d242330d088dc152b92e509265ececb8627dea2
Implements: blueprint flavor-id-metric

commit_message:
Include cisco plugin in migration plugins with ovs

Currently we have many migration files with missing cisco
plugin in migrate_plugin when ovs is included.This
causes missing tables when cisco plugin is enabled
and migration is run. This fix should automatically
include the cisco plugin if ovs is detected in the
migrate_plugins.

Change-Id: I4dedfbafe9b431e85255d5427766e22eed09ee5e
Closes-Bug: #1292114
(cherry-picked from f23d081b26071e1b309f49e5a5ab0cdc1a739e9d )

commit_message:
Change report_interval from 4 to 30, agent_down_time from 9 to 75

report_interval is how often an agent sends out a heartbeat to the
service. The Neutron service responds to these 'report_state' RPC
messages by updating the agent's heartbeat DB record.
The last heartbeat is then compared to the configured
agent_down_time to determine if the agent is up or down.
The agent's status is used when scheduling networks on DHCP
and L3 agents.

In the spirit of sane defaults suited for production, these values
should be bumped to reduce the load on the Neutron service
dramatically, freeing up CPU time to perform intensive operations.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1293083

(cherry picked from commit e13d19cab384a9f5f8a00436ad39118f342af32c)
Change-Id: I77bcf8f66f74ba55513c989caead1f96c92b9832
Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/common/config.py

deleted_lines: cfg.IntOpt('report_interval', default=4, help=_('Seconds between nodes reporting state to server; ' 'should be less than agent_down_time, best if it ' 'is half or less than agent_down_time.')),

commit_message:
Change repeater to retry on error

 * Retry is only attempted if task responds with error. Successful tasks do
not have to be retried which is the primary difference repeat and retry.

* Once a retry is triggered delay and break-on are taken into considertaion.
Modified tests appropriately and renamed types and properties appropriately.

Change-Id: I660cac05c20e791c0620add99d9d348f4bd910d1

commit_message:
Updates to the neutron install section

Update a few elements to try to make things clearer:
- turn the warning about commenting [service_providers] into a step to
  make sure that the user will do it.
- use a keystone command to compute the SERVICE_TENANT_ID value
  (RHEL/SUSE).
- simplify the 'ln -s' command to avoid changing directory.

Change-Id: Id76ba3a4ade0753522a4d49bdd4d8bcec8b56d62

commit_message:
Use cached db object in volume_mig_status ext

There is no need to rerequest the volume object from the db in
the extension because we already have a cached copy in the request.
This can potentially save hundreds of db queries in list.

Change-Id: I46da8c7b6c2af2435d246ebd8e95d4712065f1e7
Resolves-bug: 1308255

commit_message:
Improved quota error message

Removed two negatives and showed a clear message when
tried to see quota of different tenants.
When a user who does not belong to a project tries to access the
quota of that project, the message that gets displayed is not clear.
In this change the user would understand the error more properly.

Change-Id: I2284df07687bb530fe06fbaab38e2971826b7b40
Closes-Bug: #1288915

commit_message:
Nuage Plugin: Delete router requires precommit checks

There exist a case where deleting router from neutron without
deleting router-interface deletes router from VSD but not from neutron.
If router has an interface with subnet router deletion is not allowed.
Needs to precheck this condition before deleting router from
backend (VSD).

Change-Id: I4ba7eff399acda0427505328355dbfb931d62587
Closes-Bug: #1298635

commit_message:
Removed unused code

Removed unused methods, variables, and arguments
from method signature. Method 'remove_user' was
removed because method 'add_user' is unused and if
we never do add_user then no reason to do remove_user.

Change-Id: I0ef900232bc26b91e9cd192ba29a720ff7de27a3

subject: Make network_cache more robust with neutron
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-01 23:14:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1299f4315d6b3785166b72c8c392b812ea5ab025', 'message': "Make network_cache more robust with neutron

Currently, nova treats neutron as the source of truth for which ports are
attached to an instance which is a false assumption. Because of this
if someone creates a port in neutron with a device_id that matches one
of their existing instance_ids that port will eventually show up in
nova list (through the periodic heal task).

This problem usually manifests it's self when nova-compute
calls to neutron to create a port and the request times out (though
the port is actually created in neutron). When this occurs the instance
can be rescheduled on another compute node which it will call out to
neutron again to create a port. In this case two ports will show
up in the network_cache table (since they have the same instance_id) though
only one port is attached to the instance.

This patch addresses this issue by only adding ports to network_cache
if nova successfully allocated the port (or it was passed in). This
way these ghost ports are avoided. A follow up patch will come later
that garbage collects these ports.

Closes-bug: #1258620
Closes-bug: #1272195

Conflicts:

	nova/network/neutronv2/api.py

Change-Id: I961c224d95291727c8614174de07805a0d0a9e46

commit_message:
Make network_cache more robust with neutron

Currently, nova treats neutron as the source of truth for which ports are
attached to an instance which is a false assumption. Because of this
if someone creates a port in neutron with a device_id that matches one
of their existing instance_ids that port will eventually show up in
nova list (through the periodic heal task).

This problem usually manifests it's self when nova-compute
calls to neutron to create a port and the request times out (though
the port is actually created in neutron). When this occurs the instance
can be rescheduled on another compute node which it will call out to
neutron again to create a port. In this case two ports will show
up in the network_cache table (since they have the same instance_id) though
only one port is attached to the instance.

This patch addresses this issue by only adding ports to network_cache
if nova successfully allocated the port (or it was passed in). This
way these ghost ports are avoided. A follow up patch will come later
that garbage collects these ports.

Closes-bug: #1258620
Closes-bug: #1272195

Conflicts:

	nova/network/neutronv2/api.py

Change-Id: I961c224d95291727c8614174de07805a0d0a9e46
(cherry picked from commit 46922068ac167f492dd303efb359d0c649d69118)

commit_message:
Rename instance_actions v3 plugin tests to server_actions

* Renames the os-instance_actions v3 plugin tests to os-server-actions
* Also modifies JSON v3 client to use os-server-actions
* Skip get_server_actions and list_server_actions json tests
* This is required because changing name of v3 ext os-instance-actions
* to os-server-actions.

Closes-Bug: #1206032

DocImpact

Required-By: Id5049e10f5ef540d0d8e3871d800e9d9cb33da73

Change-Id: Ia493d4838dee4a8a587d12a55f16afeb143d959d

commit_message:
Add security details to keysone docs

First draft of adding keystone security docs produced
by nkinder.

Change-Id: I6f527daa222b6f54a7bf1f5cdb372909b68bff44
Co-Authored-By: Steve Martinelli <stevemar@ca.ibm.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/40/86140/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. ========================= Keystone Security Details ========================= General ======= This page documents security related details for the Keystone project. Implemented Crypto ================== None. Used Crypto =========== Libraries ~~~~~~~~~ * oauthlib (uses hashlib) * OpenSSL * PassLib * PyCrypto * hashlib * python-ldap (ultimately uses GnuTLS, NSS, or OpenSSL depends on platform) * requests (for keystoneclient HTTPS usage - need to investigate underlying crypto usage) Encryption Algorithms ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * Memcache backend encryption * Algorithm: AES * Configurable: No * Implementation: PyCrypto * Source: * keystoneclient/middleware/memcache_crypt.py * Details: * Optionally used for encrypting the token backend. * PKI token signing * Algorithm: RSA * Configurable: Yes * Implementation: OpenSSL * Source: * keystone/common/openssl.py * keystoneclient/common/cms.py * Details: * 2048, sha1 defaults * Configurable via openssl.conf. * Keys/Certs can be created outside of Keystone and dropped in. Hashing Algorithms ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * Token hashing * Algorithm: md5 * Configurable: No * Implementation: hashlib * Source: * keystoneclient/utils.py * keystoneclient/common/cms.py * Details: * Hash is used as an internal identifier in the token backend. * The data being hashed is the entire cryptographically signed token (which uses the configured signing key). The chance for collisions should be low. * S3 credentials * Algorithm: md5 * Configurable: No * Implementation: hashlib * Source: * keystone/contrib/s3/core.py * Details: * Used for signature validation of S3 credentials. * Required for S3 compatibility, so it can't be configurable. * LDAP password hashing * Algorithm: md5 * Configurable: No * Implementation: PassLib * Source: * keystone/common/utils.py * Details: * Salted using PassLib default (currently 4 bytes). * OAuth1 * Algorithm: sha1 * Configurable: No * Implementation: oauthlib * Source: * keystone/contrib/oauth1/core.py * keystone/contrib/oauth1/verifier.py * Details: * Used for signature validation of OAuth1 tokens. * Keystone only uses the HMAC*SHA1 signature for OAuth1 tokens (as described in RFC 5849). * OAuth support can be disabled. * EC2 tokens * Algorithm: sha256 * Configurable: No * Implementation: hashlib * Source: * keystone/credential/controllers.py * keystone/common/utils.py * keystoneclient/contrib/ec2/utils.py * Details: * Required for EC2 compatibility, so it can't be configurable. * Memcache signing * Algorithm: sha384 * Configurable: No * Implementation: hashlib * Source: * keystoneclient/middleware/memcache_crypt.py * Details: * Used for signing and verification when memcache encryption is enabled. * Password hashing * Algorithm: sha512 * Configurable: No * Implementation: PassLib * Source: * keystone/common/utils.py * Details: * The algorithm is non-configurable, but the number of rounds is configurable via CONF.crypt_strength (default=40000). Sensitive Data ============== Keys/Certificates ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * PKI signing key - Protected via filesystem ownership/permissions. * SSL/TLS key - Protected via filesystem ownership/permissions. Passwords ~~~~~~~~~ * SSL/TLS must be enabled in Keystone to prevent clients from sending passwords over the network in clear-text. * Passwords are truncated to a maximum length prior to hashing * Configurable via CONF.identity.max_password_length (default=4096) * SQL Identity * Password hashes are stored in SQL database. * SSL/TLS can be used to protect the connection to the database. * LDAP Identity * SSL/TLS must be used for connections to LDAP to prevent Keystone from sending passwords over the network in clear-text. Tokens ~~~~~~ * Signed tokens are stored in their entirety in one of the following backends: * KVS * Memcached * Ephemeral storage. * Able to use AES encryption and sha384 signing. * SQL (default) * Persistent storage. * SSL/TLS can be used to protect the connection to the database. * Expired tokens are not automatically removed from the backend. The `keystone-manage token_flush` command should be used to periodically remove expired tokens (via cron). Potential Improvements ====================== * Eliminate LDAP user password hashing. This code should be unnecessary, as passwords supplied by clients should only be used to perform LDAP bind operations and never stored locally in any form. * Allow all hashing schemes to be configurable where not restricted by compatibility requirements (such as S3 and EC2) * The use of md5 for token hashing is the biggest concern, as it's use is discouraged (or disallowed in the case of FIPS). Changes are in progress to make this configurable in Juno. The default should be sha256 if possible. * Allow support for LDAP SASL bind methods(such as DIGEST-MD5 and GSSAPI). * Allow other forms of external authentication to avoid using passwords (Kerberos, SAML).

commit_message:
Sync with oslo-incubator 2fd457b

This syncs Keystone with oslo-incubator commit hash
2fd457bf2ccbeb2b84ffb204778b6417cd5405ba .

In keystone:

 $ rm -r keystone/openstack/common

In oslo-incubator:

 $ python update.py ../keystone

The newer lockutils requires posix_ipc. It's already in
global-requirements.

Keystone uses gettextutils and versionutils from oslo-incubator
so those should be in openstack-common.conf. They were pulled in
as dependencies of other oslo-incubator modules but Keystone
shouldn't rely on that.

Keystone doesn't use log_handler directly so that module was
removed from openstack-common.conf. log_handler is available in
the oslo.messaging library.

Change-Id: I6082f4e0995ca35372f9b061d8f76890aa93250c

added_lines: # Copyright 2013 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ A temporary helper which emulates oslo.messaging.Notifier. This helper method allows us to do the tedious porting to the new Notifier API as a standalone commit so that the commit which switches us to oslo.messaging is smaller and easier to review. This file will be removed as part of that commit. """ from oslo.config import cfg from keystone.openstack.common.notifier import api as notifier_api CONF = cfg.CONF class Notifier(object): def __init__(self, publisher_id): super(Notifier, self).__init__() self.publisher_id = publisher_id _marker = object() def prepare(self, publisher_id=_marker): ret = self.__class__(self.publisher_id) if publisher_id is not self._marker: ret.publisher_id = publisher_id return ret def _notify(self, ctxt, event_type, payload, priority): notifier_api.notify(ctxt, self.publisher_id, event_type, priority, payload) def audit(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): # No audit in old notifier. self._notify(ctxt, event_type, payload, 'INFO') def debug(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self._notify(ctxt, event_type, payload, 'DEBUG') def info(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self._notify(ctxt, event_type, payload, 'INFO') def warn(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self._notify(ctxt, event_type, payload, 'WARN') warning = warn def error(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self._notify(ctxt, event_type, payload, 'ERROR') def critical(self, ctxt, event_type, payload): self._notify(ctxt, event_type, payload, 'CRITICAL') def get_notifier(service=None, host=None, publisher_id=None): if not publisher_id: publisher_id = "%s.%s" % (service, host or CONF.host) return Notifier(publisher_id)

subject: Fix test_multithreading on Python 3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-31 10:53:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient/commit/5bfe21e1ad22ee9e6b8554396fef37f865d2ec21', 'message': 'Fix test_multithreading on Python 3

* "print >>stream, item" doesn't work on Python 3 anymore use
  "from __future__ import print_function" to get the same syntax on Python 2
  and Python 3.

* Remove also sys.stdout and sys.stderr from MultiThreadingManager constructor
  prototype: get these streams in the constructor (at runtime) because they may
  be changed at runtime (especially during tests).

* The printer now emits Unicode strings, unicode characters are no more
  escaped.

Change-Id: I89471019d691a46651312d6a49964b719192148a

commit_message:
Fix test_multithreading on Python 3

* On Python 3, the printer doesn't encode Unicode to utf8 anymore, since
  print() expects a Unicode string.

* Update unit tests for Python 3 since repr() doesn't escape non-ASCII
  characters in Unicode strings anymore:
  http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3138/

Change-Id: I89471019d691a46651312d6a49964b719192148a

The error handling code that gets connections reset if necessary
caught ConnectionError.  It really needs to catch MessagingError,
which ConnectionError inherits from.  There are other types of
MessagingErrors that may occur, such as InternalError, and they need
to cause the connection to reset, as well.

Closes-bug: #1303890
Change-Id: Ic5082b74a362ded8b35cbc75cf178fe6e0db62d0

commit_message:
Update ensure()/reconnect() to catch MessagingError

The error handling code that gets connections reset if necessary
caught ConnectionError.  It really needs to catch MessagingError,
which ConnectionError inherits from.  There are other types of
MessagingErrors that may occur, such as InternalError, and they need
to cause the connection to reset, as well.

Closes-bug: #1303890
Change-Id: Ic5082b74a362ded8b35cbc75cf178fe6e0db62d0
(cherry picked from commit bb6f3f11f3d65e104faa8dc4ee1b880d0c6394a4)

commit_message:
Add tox option to generate HTML pages of specs

'tox -e html'  (or just 'make' if requirements are already installed)

This will use rst2html to generate a .html for each .rst spec for your
local viewing pleasure.

Change-Id: If3cd65cb251f0068f1d98cb9cab3d9aedf365209
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/34/87834/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:html] commands = make {posargs} whitelist_externals = make

commit_message:
Allow fetching jobboard implementations

To provide a standard way to fetch jobboards
that doesn't require importing the modules themselves
but by using entrypoints instead.

Blueprint jobboard-entrypoints

Change-Id: I13639c6be78a5d003e50e6cfd452c7b810072006
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/34/84934/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (C) 2014 Yahoo! Inc. All Rights Reserved. import logging import six from stevedore import driver from taskflow import exceptions as exc # NOTE(harlowja): this is the entrypoint namespace, not the module namespace. BACKEND_NAMESPACE = 'taskflow.jobboards' LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def fetch(conf, namespace=BACKEND_NAMESPACE, **kwargs): # NOTE(harlowja): this allows simpler syntax. if isinstance(conf, six.string_types): conf = {'board': conf} board = conf['board'] name = conf.get('name') LOG.debug('Looking for %r jobboard driver in %r', board, namespace) try: mgr = driver.DriverManager(namespace, board, invoke_on_load=True, invoke_args=(name, conf), invoke_kwds=kwargs) return mgr.driver except RuntimeError as e: raise exc.NotFound("Could not find jobboard %s: %s" % (board, e))
deleted_lines: # Copyright (C) 2013 Yahoo! Inc. All Rights Reserved.

commit_message:
Upgrade requirements to alembic

in ceilometer, currently the alembic>=0.4.1, in between 0.4.2 release and
0.5 release, the argument name in 'drop_constraint' and 'create_index' methods
changed from tablename to table_name. it best to upgrade the requirements to
alembic >= 0.5.

Change-Id: I3f81b17d0b39fa7a956920fc374009f40474dd92
Closes-bug: #1267284

deleted_lines: alembic>=0.4.1

commit_message:
map-services: add apache2 in the list

apache2 service is called httpd on Fedora and RHEL unlike SUSE,
Debian and Ubuntu.

commit_message:
Remove map-services from fedora element

This was supposed to have been moved to the redhat-common element,
and having it here too is both confusing and may break builds
depending on which version gets used.

Change-Id: Icae5cc633e9e49a9ee63bd9dfc94657c6795c6f1

commit_message:
Install Guide edits

section_keystone-services.xml:
  Use "OpenStack Identity" instead of "OpenStack Identity Service" for
  service creation
section_neutron-ml2-network-node.xml:
  Explain that 10.0.1.21 is the instance tunnels network address of
  the network node.
  Give a better warning that two steps are done on the controller
  node.
section_neutron-ml2-compute-node.xml:
   Explain that 10.0.1.31 is the instance tunnels network address of
   the first compute node.

Change-Id: I57d311fd0413d8a8a13f4746465612096b302e0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/77/87777/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

This guide uses <literal>10.0.1.21</literal> for the IP address of the instance tunnels network interface on the network node.</para>

updating the object.

commit_message:
libvirt: Don't cache base image while migration

We should cache base image only if the disk file of instance is
not exists. while migration the disk is an whole one without
backing file even if it is qcow2 format, so nova needn't to
cache base image for instance, otherwise if the Glance image
is deleted, an ImageNotFound exception will be raised.
Here we also add target image exists checking after getting the
lock, otherwise we may get a broken image.

Closes-bug: #1298216
Closes-bug: #1298420
Change-Id: Icfbc03239e3aa55948942c33d37ca39ffcf471c4

commit_message:
move cleaner context users/admin into setup()

In chain of calling context method, cleaner.users are set in __init__
before user context setup which cause cleaner.users is always empty. As
a result _cleanup_users_resources is never called.

Change-Id: I2e381cae67a47123f5e2c2fc876d965136ded9df
Closes-bug: #1308188
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/61/87761/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: if "admin" in context and context["admin"]: self.admin = context["admin"]["endpoint"] if "users" in context and context["users"]: self.users = [u["endpoint"] for u in context["users"]] pass

commit_message:
Make _is_multi_host() use objects

This makes the network api _is_multi_host() method use objects
instead of direct database access so that compute manager can
call it directly.

Note that the previous unit tests for this method used the
random.choice() method to selectively test the is/is-not multihost
case. Unit tests should not be non-deterministic like this, for
coverage and stability reasons. This patch pulls out the two
possibilities for each into separate cases to ensure both are
tested.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects-juno

Change-Id: I432a759a666948f2cfaa29d82f749dc9a39141be

commit_message:
Disable oslo.messaging debug logs

oslo.messaging debug logs are too verbose, turn them off. A similar patch
dropped nova-conductor logs in the gate down from 7MB to under 300K.

Cherry-Pick from oslo-incubator since we are in feature freeze:
Ia12c003dae196e2220a5f6ea768758a75f2ede23 and
Icc61964c6a2b002ac1c8566f174e6a5230674c75

Change-Id: I9e6456f1c979d9a57fc7fa93fb290c6a26017373
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/20/82620/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'oslo.messaging=INFO', 'cinder.openstack=INFO',

commit_message:
Fixes HP LeftHand driver with Paramiko 1.13.0

With Paramiko 1.13.0, the method exec_command now returns Unicode.
This causes a problem when the driver tries to build the XML returned
from the LeftHand array. The XML header returned from the array defines
the encoding as encoding=UTF-8. Therefore, we must now ensure the
encoding passed to the parser is utf-8.

Change-Id: I7b504626e2d9a0ee2b62820b11f56eb136e31987
closes-bug: #1298608

commit_message:
Fix swiftclient.client.quote() for Python 3

On Python 3, urllib.parse.quote() accepts bytes and str (unicode) types and
always return str (unicode).

Add also more tests with non-ASCII characters.

Change-Id: I8e0f19da7240e874392327d0da074ed4abb7d213
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/02/84102/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if six.PY2: def quote(value, safe='/'): """ Patched version of urllib.quote that encodes utf8 strings before quoting """ value = encode_utf8(value) if isinstance(value, bytes): return _quote(value, safe) else: return value else: quote = _quote
deleted_lines: def quote(value, safe='/'): """ Patched version of urllib.quote that encodes utf8 strings before quoting """ value = encode_utf8(value) if isinstance(value, bytes): return _quote(value, safe) else: return value

commit_message:
Update ensure()/reconnect() to catch MessagingError

The error handling code that gets connections reset if necessary
caught ConnectionError. It really needs to catch MessagingError,
which ConnectionError inherits from. There are other types of
MessagingErrors that may occur, such as InternalError, and they need
to cause the connection to reset, as well.

This fix has already been merged into oslo.messaging.

--

Cherry-picked from master 9a830b370551019a4bd3a0c7504f48961e755bd4
Cherry-picked from oslo-incubator 234f64d608266f43d8856ff98c89ceba6699d752
See also https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1086077

Change-Id: Ic5082b74a362ded8b35cbc75cf178fe6e0db62d0
Closes-bug: #1303890

commit_message:
Enable flake8 H303,H304 checking

We had two types of wildcard imports in the code. Unneeded ones
in test files that are just removed, and some that we actually
want which are kept using the '#noqa' comment to tell flake8
to skip specific checks (such as H303) for that line.

Change-Id: I7d194a7bbcccdba419a2a49a919e17c047633cf0

commit_message:
Add support for multiple RPC workers under Metaplugin

Metaplugin needs a fix to support multiple RPC workers properly
because a plugin which supports multiple RPC workers cannot
initialize RPC connections at plugin initialization.

Closes-Bug: #1300570
Change-Id: I584f70abb8969054cd4edc8f914d00f6be930bab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/14/84914/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.service import multiple_rpc_workers_supported self.rpc_flavor = cfg.CONF.META.rpc_flavor if self.rpc_flavor and self.rpc_flavor != flavor: if self.rpc_flavor and self.rpc_flavor not in self.plugins: self.rpc_flavor) # If the plugin specified by rpc_flavor supports multiple RPC workers, # set 'start_rpc_listener' of the class so that RPC initialization # will work properly later in neutron/service.py. #NOTE: It assumes specifying rpc_flavor but it is desirable to specify # rpc_flavor anyway. if self.rpc_flavor: rpc_plugin = self.plugins[self.rpc_flavor] if multiple_rpc_workers_supported(rpc_plugin): setattr(self.__class__, 'start_rpc_listener', self._start_rpc_listener) def _start_rpc_listener(self): return self.plugins[self.rpc_flavor].start_rpc_listener()
deleted_lines: rpc_flavor = cfg.CONF.META.rpc_flavor if rpc_flavor and rpc_flavor != flavor: if rpc_flavor and rpc_flavor not in self.plugins: rpc_flavor)

commit_message:
Implement locking in abandon stack

This change implements locking in abandon stack. If lock
acquire fails throws ActionInPrgoress exception.

Change-Id: I930123efa95b2863c4e2de01f4646b6e3d68c5cc
Closes-bug: #1301311

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import argparse import logging import os import sys import yaml GRID = None ALLOWED_BRANCHES = ('havana', 'icehouse', 'master') FORMAT = '%(asctime)s %(levelname)s: %(message)s' logging.basicConfig(format=FORMAT) LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def parse_features(fname): with open(fname) as f: return yaml.load(f) def normalize_branch(branch): if branch.startswith("stable/"): branch = branch[len("stable/"):] if branch not in ALLOWED_BRANCHES: LOG.error("unknown branch name %s" % branch) sys.exit(1) return branch def configs_from_env(): configs = [] for k, v in os.environ.iteritems(): if k.startswith('DEVSTACK_GATE_'): if v == '1': f = k.split('DEVSTACK_GATE_')[1] configs.append(f.lower()) return configs def calc_services(branch, features): services = set() for feature in features: services.update(GRID['features'][feature]['base'].get('services', [])) if branch in GRID['features'][feature]: services.update( GRID['features'][feature][branch].get('services', [])) # deletes always trump adds for feature in features: services.difference_update( GRID['features'][feature]['base'].get('rm-services', [])) if branch in GRID['features'][feature]: services.difference_update( GRID['features'][feature][branch].get('rm-services', [])) return sorted(list(services)) def calc_features(branch, configs=[]): LOG.debug("Branch: %s" % branch) LOG.debug("Configs: %s" % configs) features = set(GRID['config']['default'][branch]) # do all the adds first for config in configs: if config in GRID['config']: features.update(GRID['config'][config].get('features', [])) # removes always trump for config in configs: if config in GRID['config']: features.difference_update( GRID['config'][config].get('rm-features', [])) return sorted(list(features)) def get_opts(): usage = """ Compute the test matrix for devstack gate jobs from a combination of environmental feature definitions and flags. """ parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description=usage) parser.add_argument('-f', '--features', default='features.yaml', help="Yaml file describing the features matrix") parser.add_argument('-b', '--branch', default="master", help="Branch to compute the matrix for") parser.add_argument('-m', '--mode', default="services", help="What to return (services, compute-ext)") return parser.parse_args() def main(): global GRID opts = get_opts() GRID = parse_features(opts.features) branch = normalize_branch(opts.branch) features = calc_features(branch, configs_from_env()) LOG.debug("Features: %s " % features) services = calc_services(branch, features) LOG.debug("Services: %s " % services) if opts.mode == "services": print ",".join(services) if __name__ == "__main__": sys.exit(main())

commit_message:
Change bad client version for glance

Use glanceclient version '2' because version '1' does not support
creating and updating 'tags'

Also added a mock in test_clients.py to prevent a failure when
using the real Client.

Change-Id: I3c5b215bfe9c229e83495fa3cb02ad70eb9733bc

commit_message:
Refactor the driver fields mapping

Refactor the driver fields mapping into classes, the idea is to have one
class per driver type (pxe, seamicro, agent, etc...). The old mapping was
hard to extend, for e.g in case of converting one of the values before
sending the request to Ironic wasn't possible (swap_mb -> swap_gb).

This patch also minimize the number of requests sent to the Ironic API
when adding/cleaning up the nodes attributes, instead of sending 1
request per attribute it will condense everything in one request to
avoid bombarding the API service.

Change-Id: Ibfd0a8051dc84740b42c2ad46dbdbe1ed00cbdf1

commit_message:
Rename HTTPError -> HttpError

With the move to the apiclient exceptions from oslo the basic HTTP error
class was renamed. This was not reflected in all places in the code.

It was also not picked up by the tests because the apiclient tests
weren't running due to a missing __init__.py file. Because this should
be backwards compatible it was added to the list in exceptions, the
check that this is available is in the (now running) apiclient tests.

Blueprint: common-client-library-2
Change-Id: I307c1083f29e3207cc86aa938043270e5c32b4bb

commit_message:
Prefer () to continue line per PEP8

There were some long lines that were split using \ rather than ().
PEP8 recommends using () --
http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#maximum-line-length

Change-Id: I8e140e507d0d9991094be13ebafa7fc700c1a02e

commit_message:
Improve test_load_balancer_basic

This patch introduces multiple improvements of test_load_balancer_basic.

 1. Use inetd instead of nc on backends.
    Running nc in a while True cycle proved to be ineffective
    and unreliable in case of a relatively big number of
    requests.
 2. Add doc string to NeutronRetriever.
 3. Add setUp method and cleanups for resources
    as a preparation for adding more tests.
 4. Other minor fixes of storing internal values.

Change-Id: I8b5426c9cc832cb8bb5024952535f312cd627d1e

commit_message:
Add Pillow for stevedore doc build

As part of setting up gate jobs for stevedore, we have turned on
a doc build gate job. That job is failing because it can't install
Pillow. Nothing else uses Pillow, and it is not a runtime dependency
of stevedore.

Change-Id: I96c80ce571bae71ef1b867b0c4f60572fa9a4c5c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/47/85047/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Pillow==2.4.0 # MIT

commit_message:
Remove device_exists in LinuxBridgeManager

LinuxBridgeManager is adding a device_exists method instead of
using the one in ip_lib as the rest of the codebase

Change-Id: Ibeb95be76a1e1b20c69841e708c2a2cbf1cbe05a
Closes-Bug: #1302463

commit_message:
Up the default timeout for stack builds

This commit ups the default stack build timeout from 600 to 1200.
The stack frequently can take longer than 600 secs to build so
doubling it should give us a safe margin.

Related-Bug: #1297560

Change-Id: I3b13a225793d42e2fa9f4871b2fe81c745954c56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/91/87691/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Moves test database setup/teardown into a fixture

Change-Id: Ic59eb0a6f7d20abfcc2966a7162406cf541306b2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/51/85651/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.tests.ksfixtures import database self.useFixture(database.Database(self.get_extensions()))
deleted_lines: import shutilfrom keystone.common import sql from keystone.common.sql import migration_helpersfrom keystone.openstack.common.db.sqlalchemy import migrationdef _setup_database(extensions=None): if CONF.database.connection != tests.IN_MEM_DB_CONN_STRING: db = tests.dirs.tmp('test.db') pristine = tests.dirs.tmp('test.db.pristine') if os.path.exists(db): os.unlink(db) if not os.path.exists(pristine): migration.db_sync(sql.get_engine(), migration_helpers.find_migrate_repo()) for extension in (extensions or []): migration_helpers.sync_database_to_version(extension=extension) shutil.copyfile(db, pristine) else: shutil.copyfile(pristine, db) def _teardown_database(): sql.cleanup() def setup_database(self): _setup_database(self.get_extensions()) def teardown_database(self): _teardown_database() self.addCleanup(self.teardown_database) self.setup_database()

commit_message:
Return 'trigger_uri' on assembly create and show

On assembly create, solum will generate a trigger_uri which needs to
be returned to the user. The user will then add this uri to his/her
git repo as a webhook. When a git push is done on this repo, a POST
request will be sent to the trigger_uri which will then start the
build and deploy workflow.

Change-Id: I4add3d10634f7ab4d41af948bde0bc2747d00dde

commit_message:
Don't encode as UTF8 under python3

Since this is already on UTF8 and if we do it would just get converted
as bytes and fails.

Change-Id: Ibde2914e45fcc5d1bc74eebb7241f92037e0cd8c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/06/87306/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Don't encode as UTF8 in py3 since this is already encoded as # there by default and if not this would implictely be converted # as string. if six.PY3: return value

commit_message:
Add ability to configure any catalog driver

Add a catalog_driver parameter which can be used to bypass
the catalog_type parameter and offer finer control over
the catalog driver configuration in Keystone.

Conflicts:
  manifests/init.pp

Closes-bug: #1301592
Change-Id: If062c855c875cf06e192593181898ba0a185a91a
(cherry picked from commit cc0150532c5bc5e6498609132cc97ced3d20985b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/63/87763/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [catalog_driver] Catalog driver used by Keystone to store endpoints and services. Optional. # Setting this value will override and ignore catalog_type. $catalog_driver = false, if ! $catalog_driver { validate_re($catalog_type, 'template|sql') } if $catalog_driver { $catalog_driver_real = $catalog_driver } elsif ($catalog_type == 'template') { $catalog_driver_real = 'keystone.catalog.backends.templated.TemplatedCatalog' keystone_config { 'catalog/template_file': value => '/etc/keystone/default_catalog.templates' } } elsif ($catalog_type == 'sql') { $catalog_driver_real = 'keystone.catalog.backends.sql.Catalog' } keystone_config { 'catalog/driver': value => $catalog_driver_real }
deleted_lines: validate_re($catalog_type, 'template|sql') if($catalog_type == 'template') { keystone_config { 'catalog/driver': value => 'keystone.catalog.backends.templated.TemplatedCatalog'; 'catalog/template_file': value => '/etc/keystone/default_catalog.templates'; } } elsif($catalog_type == 'sql' ) { keystone_config { 'catalog/driver': value => ' keystone.catalog.backends.sql.Catalog' } }

commit_message:
Drop bunch dependency

Instead use hand-written muranodashboard.common.utils.Bunch class.

Change-Id: I8982dda81a0d2dac09bf49e0c9ffcfc2d67f84e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/11/86811/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. class Bunch(object): def __init__(self, **kwargs): for key, value in kwargs.iteritems(): setattr(self, key, value) def __getattr__(self, item): if not hasattr(self, item): return None def __getitem__(self, item): return getattr(self, item) def __setitem__(self, key, value): setattr(self, key, value) def __delitem__(self, key): delattr(self, key) def __contains__(self, item): return hasattr(self, item) def __iter__(self): return iter(self.__dict__.iteritems()) class Service(Bunch): @property def id(self): return self['?']['id'] @property def units(self): def collect_units(srv): units = [] def rec(obj): if 'host' in obj: units.append(obj['host']) elif hasattr(obj, '__iter__'): for item in obj: rec(item) rec(srv) return units return collect_units(self)

commit_message:
Add functional tests to verify ovs_lib VXLAN detection

This commit adds a functional test to verify host VXLAN support. It compares
the results of this functional test with the logic in ovs_lib to ensure both
report the same values.

Closes-Bug: #1301101

Change-Id: Id91c755d762bea134cc451952d0f13d64576663a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/04/84604/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Cisco Systems, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os from neutron.agent.linux import ovs_lib from neutron.agent.linux import utils from neutron.tests import base class TestOVSAgentVXLAN(base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestOVSAgentVXLAN, self).setUp() self._check_test_requirements() # Emulate using a rootwrap script with sudo self.root_helper = 'sudo sudo' def _check_command(self, cmd, error_text, skip_msg): try: utils.execute(cmd) except RuntimeError as e: if error_text in str(e): self.skipTest(skip_msg) raise def _check_test_requirements(self): if os.environ.get('OS_SUDO_TESTING') not in base.TRUE_STRING: self.skipTest('testing with sudo is not enabled') self._check_command(['which', 'ovs-vsctl'], 'Exit code: 1', 'ovs-vsctlis not installed') self._check_command(['sudo', '-n', 'ovs-vsctl', 'show'], 'Exit code: 1', 'password-less sudo not granted for ovs-vsctl') def invasive_vxlan_test(self): if os.environ.get('OS_SUDO_TESTING') not in base.TRUE_STRING: self.skipTest('testing with sudo is not enabled') # Create the OVS Bridge self.br = ovs_lib.OVSBridge("vxbr0", self.root_helper) # Add a tunnel port self.vxlan_port = self.br.add_tunnel_port("vxlan0", "10.10.10.10", "10.10.10.20", p_const.TYPE_VXLAN) # Check the return value ofport = utils.execute("ovs-vsctl get Interface vxlan0 ofport") try: ofport_int = int(ofport) except (TypeError, ValueError): raise # Compare the two if ofport_int != self.vxlan_port: raise ValueError # Now verify this also works try: ovs_lib.check_ovs_vxlan_version(self.root_helper) except SystemError: self.br.destroy() raise ValueError # Now delete the bridge self.br.destroy()

"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-04-15 00:38:47.000000000', 'files': ['oslo/config/cfg.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config/commit/78225a58835eeae1d05d99cc3e76e71a2e75dab3', 'message': 'Avoid using too generic names in _Namespace

commit_message:
Avoid using too generic names in _Namespace

As _Namespace is used to hold key-values for user options,
avoid using conflict-prone names for internal purposes.
Namely, prefix ours with '_'.

For example, consider the following.

    conf.register_cli_opt(cfg.BoolOpt('parser'))

In this case, the option would get added to the namespace
object as a "parser" attribute, which would conflict with
the existing name in the object.

Change-Id: Ibaf8408a118e07a8a598f87ac10a91312683df40
Closes-Bug: #1284969
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/33/76433/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: namespace.add_parsed_config_file(sections, normalized) self.conf = conf self.parser = MultiConfigParser() self.files_not_found = [] namespace = _Namespace(self.conf) namespace.parser._add_parsed_config_file(sections, normalized) for opt, group in sorted(self.conf._all_cli_opts()): def add_parsed_config_file(self, sections, normalized): self.parser._add_parsed_config_file(sections, normalized) self.files_not_found.append(config_file) values = self.parser._get(names, multi=multi, normalized=True) if self._namespace.files_not_found: raise ConfigFilesNotFoundError(self._namespace.files_not_found) if namespace.files_not_found: raise ConfigFilesNotFoundError(namespace.files_not_found)

from the nova-specs repository and has been slightly tweaked for neutron.

commit_message:
orchestration API refactor test_list_resources

Rework test_list_resources so we do a more explicit test of the
resource list which is returned - we expect exactly one resource,
so using assertIn is less explicit than assertEqual.  Refactoring
the code which reads and validates the resource list will enable
other tests to more easily reuse the resource-listing code.

Change-Id: I0c1cb52d92f609781ee21dd3f7d52ceef85e0766

added_lines: def _list_resources(self, stack_identifier): """Get a dict mapping of resource names to types. resp, resources = self.client.list_resources(stack_identifier) return dict((r['resource_name'], r['resource_type']) for r in resources) @attr(type='gate') def test_list_resources(self): """Getting list of created resources for the stack should be possible. """ resources = self._list_resources(self.stack_identifier) self.assertEqual({self.resource_name: self.resource_type}, resources)
deleted_lines: @attr(type='gate') def test_list_resources(self): """Getting list of created resources for the stack should be possible. resp, resources = self.client.list_resources(self.stack_identifier) resources_names = map(lambda resource: resource['logical_resource_id'], resources) self.assertIn(self.resource_name, resources_names) resources_types = map(lambda resource: resource['resource_type'], resources) self.assertIn(self.resource_type, resources_types)

added_lines: For Ubuntu 12.10 server ======================= To run tests ------------ [Devops documentation](http://docs.mirantis.com/fuel-dev/devops.html) For 'make iso' -------------- [Building ISO documentation](http://docs.mirantis.com/fuel-dev/develop/env.html#building-the-fuel-iso) Important notes for Savanna and Murano tests -------------------------------------------- * Don't recommend to start tests without kvm * Put Savanna image savanna-0.3-vanilla-1.2.1-ubuntu-13.04.qcow2 (md5 9ab37ec9a13bb005639331c4275a308d) to /tmp/ before start for best performance. If Internet available the image will download automatically. * Put Murano image cloud-fedora.qcow2 (md5 6e5e2f149c54b898b3c272f11ae31125) to /tmp/ before start. Murano image available only internally. * Murano tests without Internet connection on the instances will be failed * For Murano tests execute 'export SLAVE_NODE_MEMORY=5120' before tests run. * To get heat autoscale tests passed put image F17-x86_64-cfntools.qcow2 in /tmp before start Run single OSTF tests several times ----------------------------------- * Export environment variable OSTF_TEST_NAME. Example: export OSTF_TEST_NAME='Request list of networks' * Export environment variable OSTF_TEST_RETRIES_COUNT. Example: export OSTF_TEST_RETRIES_COUNT=120 * Execute test_ostf_repetable_tests from tests_strength package sh "utils/jenkins/system_tests.sh" -t test -w $(pwd) -j "fuelweb_test" -i "$ISO_PATH" -V $(pwd)/venv/fuelweb_test -o --group=create_delete_ip_n_times_nova_flat

commit_message:
More accurate meter name and unit for host load averages

Fixes bug 1307482

Previously, the SNMP reported load averages were misleadingly metered
as percentage utilizations.

Now, these samples include a meter name and unit that more accurately
reflect their true meaning - i.e. an exponentially-damped moving average
of the number of running or runnable processes.

Change-Id: I5dbc6f7886ed9a451926b502365ec80322f6b458
(cherry picked from commit 5872c6fd12bbd3711f8a9e68adcfa70e8f8d80bc)

commit_message:
Fix typo of ANS1 to ASN1

Replace all occurrences of 'ANS1|ans1' with 'ASN1|asn1'.  Keep
cms.is_ans1_token() around for backwards compatibility.

Change-Id: I89da78b89aa9daf2637754dc93031d7ca81e85cb
Closes-bug: 1306874

commit_message:
Fix import group ordering in test_utils.py

Per the hacking guidelines the ordering for imports should be stdlib
first, followed by 3rd party imports, and last should the project
imports. However, test_utils.py did not adhere to this ordering. This
commit fixes the oversight.

Change-Id: I0fcc9d137706e841c2e22bd2af8ecd77135c78d2

commit_message:
Add load_test mechanism for InputScenarioUtils

Similar to what was done for the negative test framework this commit
adds a method to handle using CONF values with testscenarios.
Previously the attr's were set in the test class definition which
would force a getattr at import time. This will cause issues if the
config file is not present. By adding a method which won't be executed
at import but rather when the tests are run we can avoid this.

Change-Id: Ib635f8b895f6642f78a3af644170700f72259d46

added_lines: import testtools import testscenarios def load_tests_input_scenario_utils(*args): """ Wrapper for testscenarios to set the scenarios to avoid running a getattr on the CONF object at import. """ if getattr(args[0], 'suiteClass', None) is not None: loader, standard_tests, pattern = args else: standard_tests, module, loader = args scenario_utils = InputScenarioUtils() scenario_flavor = scenario_utils.scenario_flavors scenario_image = scenario_utils.scenario_images for test in testtools.iterate_tests(standard_tests): setattr(test, 'scenarios', testscenarios.multiply_scenarios( scenario_image, scenario_flavor)) return testscenarios.load_tests_apply_scenarios(*args)

commit_message:
Move the test_utils module to scenario test dir

The test_utils module in tempest.common.utils is only useful for
scenario tests. So it's a little confusing to have it in the common
directory. This commit corrects this by moving the file into the
scenario directory. The service tag requirement for scenario tests
hacking check is updated to only check scenario test files, because
a method in the new utils module was being picked up incorrectly.

Change-Id: I1d70745a5ee07923e680328e5b8a29bfb82d8099

commit_message:
Db-sync the Ceilometer database

-The Ceilometer database wasn't db-synced till now.
 The code in reset-db is not executed, seems like the
 right way is to put the sync in the API post-configure.
 Other services do it like this.

Change-Id: Ia722669b18cfbf613f3d346aaa0a248e13de7cf5

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-13 21:56:54.000000000', 'files': ['os_collect_config/collect.py', 'os_collect_config/tests/test_collect.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-collect-config/commit/6198acbfcc5f0e7357137191c55783bfd2e66895', 'message': 'Commit changes to exploded deployments to cache

Before this, the exploded deployments that the cfn collector produced
would not ever be committed, and thus would always appear to have been
changed. This resulted in os-collect-config running the command
endlessly.

This requires some refactoring so that we commit changes to the cache
based on what was actually written, rather than just the static list of
