commit_message:
Commit changes to exploded deployments to cache

Before this, the exploded deployments that the cfn collector produced
would not ever be committed, and thus would always appear to have been
changed. This resulted in os-collect-config running the command
endlessly.

This requires some refactoring so that we commit changes to the cache
based on what was actually written, rather than just the static list of
collectors.

Closes-Bug: #1307153

Change-Id: I618ef5d752ed6519e8b7bfc090de03f2f24e73ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-collect-config refs/changes/39/87139/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _test_collect_all_store(self, requests_impl_map=None, expected_changed=None): (changed_keys, paths) = self._call_collect_all( if expected_changed is None: expected_changed = set(['heat_local', 'cfn', 'ec2']) self.assertEqual(expected_changed, changed_keys) expected_changed = set(('heat_local', 'ec2', 'cfn', 'dep-name1')) self._test_collect_all_store(requests_impl_map=soft_config_map, expected_changed=expected_changed) (changed_keys, paths) = self._call_collect_all( store=True, collectors=new_list) self.assertEqual(set(cfg.CONF.collectors), changed_keys) (changed_keys, paths) = self._call_collect_all(store=True) self.assertEqual(set(cfg.CONF.collectors), changed_keys) for changed in changed_keys: cache.commit(changed) (changed_keys, paths2) = self._call_collect_all(store=True) self.assertEqual(set(), changed_keys) self.assertEqual(paths, paths2) def test_collect_all_no_change_softwareconfig(self): soft_config_map = {'ec2': test_ec2.FakeRequests, 'cfn': test_cfn.FakeRequestsSoftwareConfig(self)} (changed_keys, paths) = self._call_collect_all( store=True, requests_impl_map=soft_config_map) expected_changed = set(cfg.CONF.collectors) expected_changed.add('dep-name1') self.assertEqual(expected_changed, changed_keys) # Commit for changed in changed_keys: cache.commit(changed) (changed_keys, paths2) = self._call_collect_all( store=True, requests_impl_map=soft_config_map) self.assertEqual(set(), changed_keys) (changed_keys, content) = self._call_collect_all(store=False) self.assertEqual(set(), changed_keys) (changed_keys, content) = self._call_collect_all( self.assertEqual(set(), changed_keys)
deleted_lines: def _test_collect_all_store(self, requests_impl_map=None): (any_changed, paths) = self._call_collect_all( self.assertTrue(any_changed) self._test_collect_all_store(requests_impl_map=soft_config_map) (any_changed, paths) = self._call_collect_all(store=True, collectors=new_list) self.assertTrue(any_changed) (any_changed, paths) = self._call_collect_all(store=True) self.assertTrue(any_changed) for collector in cfg.CONF.collectors: cache.commit(collector) (any_changed, paths2) = self._call_collect_all(store=True) self.assertFalse(any_changed) (any_changed, content) = self._call_collect_all(store=False) self.assertFalse(any_changed) (any_changed, content) = self._call_collect_all( self.assertFalse(any_changed)

commit_message:
Test that collect_all works when nothing changed

This improves the test coverage for this very common case and sets up
for a new test which will expose that we fail in this case for exploded
deployments collected by the cfn collector.

Change-Id: I74807107824f8795619207389c064e83580c1c87
Related-Bug: #1307153
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-collect-config refs/changes/24/87124/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from os_collect_config import cache def test_collect_all_no_change(self): (any_changed, paths) = self._call_collect_all(store=True) self.assertTrue(any_changed) # Commit for collector in cfg.CONF.collectors: cache.commit(collector) (any_changed, paths2) = self._call_collect_all(store=True) self.assertFalse(any_changed) self.assertEqual(paths, paths2)

commit_message:
Correct orchestration stack abandon api

Heat stack abandon api has abandon data as response and when the
method is GET it will perform dry run action, means do nothing but
response the abandon data.

Change-Id: I6539b02bc5959b645c32ef758f80f5b2aa2e812d
Closes-Bug: #1307852

commit_message:
Fix dhcp-all-interfaces on Ubuntu/Debian.

We now call dhcp-all-interfaces with an argument, so it won't try and
configure all available interfaces.

Change-Id: I7dfb7d58ce3d1a92fb093099529e261c7e10e20c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/66/84466/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: exec /usr/local/sbin/dhcp-all-interfaces.sh

commit_message:
xenapi: Cleanup tar process on glance error

Currently, when the network connection to glance is interrupted, there
is different behaviour on upload and download.

This change ensures the behaviour between the two code paths is more
consistent.

Uploads generally need to be given more time before they timeout, so
to keep a single timeout between upload and download, the timeout is
increased to 90 seconds.

At the same time, it ensures the tar process gets killed when any
issues occur with the communication between the hypervisor and
glance.

Change-Id: Id5396e5d3c1052dc2979476a886412da65e08670
Closes-Bug: #1284596
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/76169/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def kill_process(proc): """Sends the given process the SIGKILL signal.""" pid = proc.pid kill_process_cmd = ["kill", "-9", pid] # NOTE(johngarbutt) can't use proc.kill() because # this code is run in python 2.4 run_command(kill_process_cmd) try: while True: chunk = tar_proc.stdout.read(CHUNK_SIZE) if chunk == '': break if callback: callback(chunk) if fileobj: fileobj.write(chunk) except: kill_process(tar_proc) raise try: while True: chunk = fileobj.read(CHUNK_SIZE) if chunk == '': break if callback: callback(chunk) tar_proc.stdin.write(chunk) except: kill_process(tar_proc) raise
deleted_lines: while True: chunk = tar_proc.stdout.read(CHUNK_SIZE) if chunk == '': break if callback: callback(chunk) if fileobj: fileobj.write(chunk) while True: chunk = fileobj.read(CHUNK_SIZE) if chunk == '': break if callback: callback(chunk) tar_proc.stdin.write(chunk)

subject: Decorated commands no longer take command_name
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-14 00:50:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent/commit/07715e9d99df88dd413b40f034e93b6b3bfb1d88', 'message': 'Decorated commands no longer take command_name

Prior to the (sync|async)_command decorators, extension methods had to
construct command results themselves, which required that they have
the name of the command being executed.

When the async_command decorator was introduced, we wanted to maintain
the current command interface, so that a command could be made
asynchronous simply by adding the decorator.

The introduction of the sync_command decorator allows us to satisfy
this objective, without requiring decorated methods to accept a
command_name. This patch modifies both decorators to no longer pass
the command_name argument, and modifies existing command methods not

commit_message:
Decorated commands no longer take command_name

Prior to the (sync|async)_command decorators, extension methods had to
construct command results themselves, which required that they have
the name of the command being executed.

When the async_command decorator was introduced, we wanted to maintain
the current command interface, so that a command could be made
asynchronous simply by adding the decorator.

The introduction of the sync_command decorator allows us to satisfy
this objective, without requiring decorated methods to accept a
command_name. This patch modifies both decorators to no longer pass
the command_name argument, and modifies existing command methods not
to expect one.

Closes-Bug: #1308021
Change-Id: I1b33bb7519588cdcb79c6f4d2b10c1e5e8c0cca3

commit_message:
Add number and file validators

 * number: Check a numeric argument specifying min, max. Optionally
           require input to be integer.
 * file_exists: Check that a file exists and can be opened

 These validators are used in the runcommand in instance benchmark
 (patch pending)

Change-Id: Ia12e95b3661c97ae6f4c54caf44fdf33b72aa736
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/55/86655/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_integer_range(self): validator = validation.integer_range('param', 0, 10, False) # Test invalid inputs result = validator(param=-1) self.assertFalse(result.is_valid) result = validator(param=11) self.assertFalse(result.is_valid) result = validator(param="not an int") self.assertFalse(result.is_valid) result = validator(param=None) self.assertFalse(result.is_valid) result = validator() self.assertFalse(result.is_valid) # Test valid inputs result = validator(param=0) self.assertTrue(result.is_valid) result = validator(param=10) self.assertTrue(result.is_valid) # Test NoneOK validator = validation.integer_range('param', 0, 10, True) result = validator(param=None) self.assertTrue(result.is_valid) result = validator() self.assertTrue(result.is_valid) result = validator(param=-1) self.assertFalse(result.is_valid) result = validator(param=0) self.assertTrue(result.is_valid) @mock.patch("__builtin__.open") def test_file_exists(self, mock_open): validator = validation.file_exists('param') result = validator(param='/tmp/foo') mock_open.assert_called_once_with('/tmp/foo', 'r') self.assertTrue(result.is_valid) mock_open.side_effect = IOError() result = validator(param='/tmp/bah') mock_open.assert_called_with('/tmp/bah', 'r') self.assertFalse(result.is_valid)

commit_message:
Don't use flake8: noqa

A line with "# flake8: noqa" disables pep8 for the entire file.
Use "# noqa" for a line.

Change-Id: Id0e4b98f02149113963af2c1da1b42d667d139d5

commit_message:
Install guide for Ironic

This contains the beginnings of documentation on how to
install and configure the Bare Metal Service (ironic).

This is modelled after documentation available at
http://docs.openstack.org/havana/install-guide/install/apt/content/.

Change-Id: I7bf0a9caaf5bd5a2fcfc6fd0b0addeedb7ca26cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/45/81645/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _ironic-install: ============== Ironic Service ============== Ironic is a collection of components that provides support to manage and provision physical machines. Ironic interacts with the Identity Service for authentication, Image Service for images, Compute Services for baremetal deployments, and the Networking Service for networking. The Ironic Service includes the following components: * ironic-api. A REST API that processes API requests by sending them to the ironic-conductor over RPC. * ironic-conductor. Adds, powers on, provisions, decommissions, and powers off baremetal nodes. * ironic client. A CLI for users to submit commands as a tenant administrator. * Database. Stores node-related information. You can choose your database, but it is typical to use the same as the Compute Service's SQL database. * A queue. A central hub for passing messages. It should use the same implementation as that of the Compute Service (typically RabbitMQ). ====================== Install Ironic Service ====================== Ironic is a collection of components that provides support to manage and provision physical machines. You can configure these components to run on separate nodes or the same node. In this guide, the components run on one node, typically the Compute service's compute node. This section shows you how to install and configure the Ironic components. It assumes that the Identity Service, Image Service, Compute Services, and Networking Service have already been set up. Configure Identity Service for Ironic ------------------------------------- 1. Create the Ironic service user (eg ``ironic``). Ironic uses this to authenticate with the Identity Service. Use the ``service`` tenant and give the user the ``admin`` role:: keystone user-create --name=ironic --pass=IRONIC_PASSWORD --email=ironic@example.com keystone user-role-add --user=ironic --tenant=service --role=admin 2. You must register Ironic with the Identity Service so that other OpenStack services can locate it. To register the service:: keystone service-create --name=ironic --type=baremetal \ --description="Ironic service" 3. Use the ``id`` property that is returned from keystone when creating the service (above), to create the endpoint, and replace IRONIC_NODE with your ironic API node:: keystone endpoint-create \ --service-id=the_service_id_above \ --publicurl=http://IRONIC_NODE:6385 \ --internalurl=http://IRONIC_NODE:6385 \ --adminurl=http://IRONIC_NODE:6385 Set up Ironic with the Database ------------------------------- 1. In MySQL, create an ``ironic`` database user:: # mysql -u root -p mysql> CREATE DATABASE ironic; mysql> GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON ironic.* TO 'ironic'@'localhost' \ IDENTIFIED BY 'IRONIC_DB_PASSWORD'; mysql> GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON ironic.* TO 'ironic'@'%' \ IDENTIFIED BY 'IRONIC_DB_PASSWORD'; Install Ironic Packages ----------------------- 1. Install these Ironic packages:: # Available in Ubuntu 14.04 (trusty) # RLOO http://packages.ubuntu.com/search?keywords=ironic # RLOO check that this works and includes all the packages needed. apt-get install ironic-api ironic-conductor python-ironic python-ironicclient # RLOO Need fedora/RHEL when packages available Configure Ironic ---------------- Ironic is configured via its configuration file. The configuration file is typically located at /etc/ironic/ironic.conf. [RLOO, how does that file get there, is it part of one of the install packages or do we need to mention where to get the sample?] [RLOO, terminology. Are the things in the configuration file options, parameters, or keys?] Although some options are mentioned here, it is recommended that you review all the available options so that Ironic is configured for your needs. 1. Ironic stores information in a database. The examples in this guide use the MySQL database that is used by other OpenStack services. Configure the location of the database via the 'connection' option. In the following, replace IRONIC_DBPASSWORD with your ironic service password, and DB_IP with the ip address where the DB server is located:: [RLOO Should we show the comments etc from the .sample, or just the options to be set?] [database] ... # The SQLAlchemy connection string used to connect to the # database (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/sql_connection # Deprecated group/name - [DATABASE]/sql_connection # Deprecated group/name - [sql]/connection #connection=<None> connection = mysql://ironic:IRONIC_DBPASSWORD@DB_IP/ironic?charset=utf8 2. Configure the Ironic Service to use the RabbitMQ message broker by setting the rabbit_host, rabbit_password and rpc_backend configuration options:: RLOO: rabbit_host or rabbit_hosts? devstack uses rabbit_hosts. Is it worth setting rpc_backend if the default is what we want? [DEFAULT] ... # The messaging module to use, defaults to kombu. (string # value) #rpc_backend=ironic.openstack.common.rpc.impl_kombu ... # The RabbitMQ broker address where a single node is used # (string value) rabbit_host=RABBIT_HOST # The RabbitMQ broker port where a single node is used # (integer value) #rabbit_port=5672 # RabbitMQ HA cluster host:port pairs (list value) #rabbit_hosts=$rabbit_host:$rabbit_port # Connect over SSL for RabbitMQ (boolean value) #rabbit_use_ssl=false # The RabbitMQ userid (string value) #rabbit_userid=guest rabbit_userid=IRONIC # The RabbitMQ password (string value) rabbit_password=RABBIT_PASSWORD 3. Set the my_ip configuration option to the internal IP address of the node:: RLOO. Do we need to mention this; the default is the IP address of the node. [DEFAULT] ... # IP address of this host. (string value) my_ip=192.168.0.10 4. Configure the Ironic service to use these credentials with the Identity service. Replace IRONIC_PASSWORD with your Ironic password:: [DEFAULT] ... auth_strategy=keystone ... [keystone_authtoken] # Host providing the admin Identity API endpoint (string # value) #auth_host=127.0.0.1 # Port of the admin Identity API endpoint (integer value) #auth_port=35357 # Protocol of the admin Identity API endpoint(http or https) # (string value) #auth_protocol=https # Complete public Identity API endpoint (string value) #auth_uri=<None> # Keystone account username (string value) #admin_user=<None> admin_user=ironic # Keystone account password (string value) #admin_password=<None> admin_password=IRONIC_PASSWORD # Keystone service account tenant name to validate user tokens # (string value) #admin_tenant_name=admin admin_tenant_name=service # Directory used to cache files related to PKI tokens (string # value) #signing_dir=<None> devstack has it set to /var/cache/ironic/api 5. Set the URL for connecting to the Networking service, to be the Networking service endpoint:: [neutron] # URL for connecting to neutron. (string value) #url=http://127.0.0.1:9696 6. Configure Ironic so that it can communicate with the Image service:: [RLOO what is really needed, glance_api_servers or glance_host?] [glance] # A list of URL schemes that can be downloaded directly via # the direct_url. Currently supported schemes: [file]. (list # value) #allowed_direct_url_schemes= # Default glance hostname or IP address. (string value) #glance_host=$my_ip # Default glance port. (integer value) #glance_port=9292 # Default protocol to use when connecting to glance. Set to # https for SSL. (string value) #glance_protocol=http # A list of the glance api servers available to nova. Prefix # with https:// for SSL-based glance API servers. Format is # [hostname|IP]:port. (string value) #glance_api_servers=<None> 7. Configure PXE. defaults might be OK? devstack has these set:: tftp_master_path = /opt/stack/data/ironic/tftpboot/master_images tftp_root = /opt/stack/data/ironic/tftpboot tftp_server = 10.0.2.15 8. Configure Ironic to use the policy file at /etc/ironic/policy.json:: [RLOO can we change the default value to be /etc/ironic/policy.json, so we don't have to mention this?] [DEFAULT] ... #policy_file=policy.json policy_file=/etc/ironic/policy.json 9. Create the Ironic service db tables:: ironic-dbsync --config-file /etc/ironic/ironic.conf 10. Restart the Ironic services:: service ironic-api restart service ironic-conductor restart

commit_message:
Improve tempest.conf generation

Class TempestConf is added that generates tempest configuration file
for specific OpenStack deployment.

Co-Authored-By: Alexander Maretskiy <amaretskiy@mirantis.com>

blueprint tempest-improve-autoconfig

Change-Id: Id0a33998f99820f8a108305eea14b9bb9918c102

commit_message:
Add documentation for ironic CLI

Adds a short description about how to get started with the
ironic CLI.

Change-Id: I86247c36d9c3ce482dde009bef7e59fcdc493c64
Partial-Bug: #1300990
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-ironicclient refs/changes/27/86127/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================================== :program:`ironic` Command-Line Interface (CLI) ============================================== .. program:: ironic .. highlight:: bash SYNOPSIS ======== :program:`ironic` [options] <command> [command-options] :program:`ironic help` :program:`ironic help` <command> DESCRIPTION =========== The :program:`ironic` command-line interface (CLI) interacts with the OpenStack Bare Metal Service (Ironic). In order to use the CLI, you must provide your OpenStack username, password, project (historically called tenant), and auth endpoint. You can use configuration options :option:`--os-username`, :option:`--os-password`, :option:`--os-tenant-id` (or :option:`--os-tenant-name`), and :option:`--os-auth-url`, or set the corresponding environment variables:: export OS_USERNAME=user export OS_PASSWORD=password export OS_TENANT_ID=b363706f891f48019483f8bd6503c54b # or OS_TENANT_NAME export OS_TENANT_NAME=project # or OS_TENANT_ID export OS_AUTH_URL=http://auth.example.com:5000/v2.0 The command-line tool will attempt to reauthenticate using the provided credentials for every request. You can override this behavior by manually supplying an auth token using :option:`--ironic-url` and :option:`--os-auth-token`, or by setting the corresponding environment variables:: export IRONIC_URL=http://ironic.example.org:6385/ export OS_AUTH_TOKEN=3bcc3d3a03f44e3d8377f9247b0ad155 OPTIONS ======= To get a list of available (sub)commands and options, run:: ironic help To get usage and options of a command, run:: ironic help <command> EXAMPLES ======== Get information about the node-create command:: ironic help node-create Get a list of available drivers:: ironic driver-list Enroll a node with "fake" deploy driver and "ipmitool" power driver:: ironic node-create -d fake_ipmitool -i ipmi_address=1.2.3.4 Get a list of nodes:: ironic node-list

commit_message:
[compute] Allow binding locally to different IP than endpoint IP

Sometimes you want the actual endpoint IP to be a load balanced IP, but
the bind IP to be a local IP (different per node).

This change allows that by using the <servicename>-bind attributes for the
actual local bind addresses

Implements blueprint increase-ip-binding-flexibility

Change-Id: Ib861d80dc97ab356297ecdc34210e43a2d768584

commit_message:
[compute] Allow binding locally to different IP than endpoint IP

Sometimes you want the actual endpoint IP to be a load balanced IP, but
the bind IP to be a local IP (different per node).

This change allows that by using the <servicename>-bind attributes for the
actual local bind addresses

Implements blueprint increase-ip-binding-flexibility

Change-Id: Ib861d80dc97ab356297ecdc34210e43a2d768584

commit_message:
Cover deployments explosion case better in tests

When cfn explodes deployments we end up with many things stored per
collector, so some assumptions around 1:1 collector to cached content
cannot be made anymore.

Change-Id: I43c5fb759bc99690e0def1c6ecb672ab7f087df8

commit_message:
Track security group provisioned by heat

Reasons:
- taskmanager doesn't perform any
associations of security
group/rules and instance.

Changes:
- adding associations for group, rules

Change-Id: I39d5ab789e39d97bd612463863216af2a86976eb
Closes-Bug: #1276228

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-15 10:52:34.000000000', 'files': ['muranoapi/db/migrate_repo/versions/007_instance_table_extended.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/4e54c4b2fb18b9010b7a821748e0fb1c6a2bdaca', 'message': "Fixed DB migration script

Bug was introduced in 4dd5c7b2f28ed85054b23ac8cf3c4664cd2d2c6e
This patched added migration script #007 which adds NOT NULL columns without
default value. It caused following error message on db-sync command:

> Cannot add a NOT NULL column with default value NULL u'\nALTER TABLE \
> instance_stats ADD type_name VARCHAR(512) NOT NULL' ()

As a fix I've added default values to columns instance.type_name and
instance.tenant_id. Default values is an empty string.

Change-Id: I33772698f015e5ee4cbc4419e212e478fa29bea2
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed DB migration script

Bug was introduced in 4dd5c7b2f28ed85054b23ac8cf3c4664cd2d2c6e
This patched added migration script #007 which adds NOT NULL columns without
default value. It caused following error message on db-sync command:

> Cannot add a NOT NULL column with default value NULL u'\nALTER TABLE \
> instance_stats ADD type_name VARCHAR(512) NOT NULL' ()

As a fix I've added default values to columns instance.type_name and
instance.tenant_id. Default values is an empty string.

Change-Id: I33772698f015e5ee4cbc4419e212e478fa29bea2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/39/87539/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: type_name = schema.Column('type_name', types.String(512), nullable=False, server_default='') tenant_id = schema.Column('tenant_id', types.String(32), nullable=False, server_default='')
deleted_lines: type_name = schema.Column('type_name', types.String(512), nullable=False) tenant_id = schema.Column('tenant_id', types.String(32), nullable=False)

commit_message:
Fix inaccurate error_msg for InvalidTemplateVersion

We should give the suggestion about the corresponding versions if the template
version is invalid while initializing a template object, instead giving the
all versions.

Change-Id: Ic1a11903e0142c68a713bd7e05c517466923571b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/61/81761/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_invalid_hot_version(self): invalid_hot_version_tmp = template_format.parse( '''{ "heat_template_version" : "2012-12-12", }''') init_ex = self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidTemplateVersion, parser.Template, invalid_hot_version_tmp) ex_error_msg = 'The template version is invalid: Unknown version ' \ '(heat_template_version: 2012-12-12). ' \ 'Should be one of: 2013-05-23' self.assertEqual(ex_error_msg, str(init_ex)) def test_invalid_aws_version(self): invalid_aws_version_tmp = template_format.parse( '''{ "AWSTemplateFormatVersion" : "2012-12-12", }''') init_ex = self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidTemplateVersion, parser.Template, invalid_aws_version_tmp) ex_error_msg = 'The template version is invalid: Unknown version ' \ '(AWSTemplateFormatVersion: 2012-12-12). ' \ 'Should be one of: 2010-09-09' self.assertEqual(ex_error_msg, str(init_ex)) def test_invalid_heat_version(self): invalid_heat_version_tmp = template_format.parse( '''{ "HeatTemplateFormatVersion" : "2010-09-09", }''') init_ex = self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidTemplateVersion, parser.Template, invalid_heat_version_tmp) ex_error_msg = 'The template version is invalid: Unknown version ' \ '(HeatTemplateFormatVersion: 2010-09-09). ' \ 'Should be one of: 2012-12-12' self.assertEqual(ex_error_msg, str(init_ex))

subject: Add point in time recovery
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-25 12:49:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration/commit/6d35dad7744222812e9c7f5b5f64f8ae4192dee1', 'message': 'Add point in time recovery

Reasons:
- Trove is able to perform instance restoration
  (whole new instance, from scratch) from previously
  stored backup in remote storage (OpenStack Swift,
  Amazon AWS S3, etc). From administration/regular
  user perspective Trove should be able to perform
  point in time recovery. Basically its almost the
  same as restoring new instance, but the difference
  between restore (in terms of Trove) and recovery is huge.
  Restore gives an ability to spin-up new instance from backup
  (as mentioned earlier), but the Recovery gives an ability

commit_message:
Add point in time recovery

Reasons:
- Trove is able to perform instance restoration
  (whole new instance, from scratch) from previously
  stored backup in remote storage (OpenStack Swift,
  Amazon AWS S3, etc). From administration/regular
  user perspective Trove should be able to perform
  point in time recovery. Basically its almost the
  same as restoring new instance, but the difference
  between restore (in terms of Trove) and recovery is huge.
  Restore gives an ability to spin-up new instance from backup
  (as mentioned earlier), but the Recovery gives an ability
  to restore already running instance from backup. For the
  beginning Trove would be able to recover/restore
  running instance from full backup.

Changes:
- adding ability to perform point in
  time recovery integration testing;

Change-Id: Ib29773ff31cd4be40bbb596aae2deddb0bcd54bb
Implements: blueprint mysql-point-in-time-recovery

commit_message:
Add point in time recovery

Reasons:
- Trove is able to perform instance restoration
  (whole new instance, from scratch) from previously
  stored backup in remote storage (OpenStack Swift,
  Amazon AWS S3, etc). From administration/regular
  user perspective Trove should be able to perform
  point in time recovery. Basically its almost the
  same as restoring new instance, but the difference
  between restore (in terms of Trove) and recovery is huge.
  Restore gives an ability to spin-up new instance from backup
  (as mentioned earlier), but the Recovery gives an ability
  to restore already running instance from backup. For the
  beginning Trove would be able to recover/restore
  running instance from full backup.

Changes:
- adding ability to perform point in
  time recovery.

Change-Id: I775e6956ef48b5bfd5002e6322212b4505ae973c
Implements: blueprint point-in-tyme-recovery

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import testtools import mock from troveclient.v1 import recovery class DBLogTests(testtools.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(DBLogTests, self).setUp() self.orig__init = recovery.Recover.__init__ recovery.Recover.__init__ = mock.Mock(return_value=None) self.recovery = recovery.Recover() self.recovery.manager = mock.Mock() def tearDown(self): super(DBLogTests, self).tearDown() recovery.Recover.__init__ = self.orig__init def test_repr(self): self.recovery.name = "recovery-1" self.assertEqual('<Recover: recovery-1>', self.recovery.__repr__())

commit_message:
Add point in time recovery

Changes:
 - adding ability to perform point in
   time recovery from given timestamp;

Changes:
 - public API proposed;
 - tests were proposed.

commit_message:
Fix drop_unique_constraint utility for sqlite

Commit c76be5bbfe added the drop_unique_constraint utility method in
Havana but the way the method exists in oslo and how it exists (and
always existed in nova for the most part) aren't the same. Worse, the
method doesn't work for sqlite in migrations since sqlalchemy-migrate's
constraint dropper for sqlite doesn't support the 'alter table drop
constraint' call.

This change replaces the current drop_unique_constraint method in oslo
with the current version from nova.  There are three related unit tests
and they are nearly identical between nova and oslo, the only difference
being the nova version in one test was dropping the tables created in
the test and the oslo version wasn't, so I added that here.

This patch is also needed to not only make the method work with sqlite
but so that nova commit 1a8dd2487 can move forward with removing several
hundred lines of duplicate code from nova so nova can switch over to
using oslo's db utility methods.

Closes-Bug: #1307266
Related-Bug: #1280055

Change-Id: Iebdbed18d5d737aab46a2ad6b99c2d8c8ee4106a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/69/87369/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from migrate.changeset import UniqueConstraint, ForeignKeyConstraintfrom sqlalchemy import schemadef _get_unique_constraints_in_sqlite(migrate_engine, table_name): regexp = "CONSTRAINT (\w+) UNIQUE \(([^\)]+)\)" meta = MetaData(bind=migrate_engine) table = Table(table_name, meta, autoload=True) sql_data = migrate_engine.execute( """ SELECT sql FROM sqlite_master WHERE type = 'table' AND name = :table_name; """, table_name=table_name ).fetchone()[0] uniques = set([ schema.UniqueConstraint( *[getattr(table.c, c.strip(' "')) for c in cols.split(",")], name=name ) for name, cols in re.findall(regexp, sql_data) ]) return uniques def _drop_unique_constraint_in_sqlite(migrate_engine, table_name, uc_name, **col_name_col_instance): insp = reflection.Inspector.from_engine(migrate_engine) meta = MetaData(bind=migrate_engine) table = Table(table_name, meta, autoload=True) columns = [] for column in table.columns: if isinstance(column.type, NullType): new_column = _get_not_supported_column(col_name_col_instance, column.name) columns.append(new_column) else: columns.append(column.copy()) uniques = _get_unique_constraints_in_sqlite(migrate_engine, table_name) table.constraints.update(uniques) constraints = [constraint for constraint in table.constraints if not constraint.name == uc_name and not isinstance(constraint, schema.ForeignKeyConstraint)] new_table = Table(table_name + "__tmp__", meta, *(columns + constraints)) new_table.create() indexes = [] for index in insp.get_indexes(table_name): column_names = [new_table.c[c] for c in index['column_names']] indexes.append(Index(index["name"], *column_names, unique=index["unique"])) f_keys = [] for fk in insp.get_foreign_keys(table_name): refcolumns = [fk['referred_table'] + '.' + col for col in fk['referred_columns']] f_keys.append(ForeignKeyConstraint(fk['constrained_columns'], refcolumns, table=new_table, name=fk['name'])) ins = InsertFromSelect(new_table, table.select()) migrate_engine.execute(ins) table.drop() [index.create(migrate_engine) for index in indexes] for fkey in f_keys: fkey.create() new_table.rename(table_name) """This method drops UC from table and works for mysql, postgresql and sqlite. In mysql and postgresql we are able to use "alter table" construction. In sqlite is only one way to drop UC: 1) Create new table with same columns, indexes and constraints (except one that we want to drop). 2) Copy data from old table to new. 3) Drop old table. 4) Rename new table to the name of old table. if migrate_engine.name == "sqlite": _drop_unique_constraint_in_sqlite(migrate_engine, table_name, uc_name, **col_name_col_instance) else: meta = MetaData() meta.bind = migrate_engine t = Table(table_name, meta, autoload=True) uc = UniqueConstraint(*columns, table=t, name=uc_name) uc.drop()
deleted_lines: """Drop unique constraint from table. DEPRECATED: this function is deprecated and will be removed from oslo.db in a few releases. Please use UniqueConstraint.drop() method directly for sqlalchemy-migrate migration scripts. This method drops UC from table and works for mysql, postgresql and sqlite. In mysql and postgresql we are able to use "alter table" construction. Sqlalchemy doesn't support some sqlite column types and replaces their type with NullType in metadata. We process these columns and replace NullType with the correct column type. from migrate.changeset import UniqueConstraint meta = MetaData() meta.bind = migrate_engine t = Table(table_name, meta, autoload=True) if migrate_engine.name == "sqlite": override_cols = [ _get_not_supported_column(col_name_col_instance, col.name) for col in t.columns if isinstance(col.type, NullType) ] for col in override_cols: t.columns.replace(col) uc = UniqueConstraint(*columns, table=t, name=uc_name) uc.drop()

commit_message:
Fix log ownership and WSGIProcess* settings for Red Hat releases

According to python-django-horizon's SPEC file log file should
be owned by user 'apache'. According to openstack-dashboard.conf
file located in the same package WSGIProcessGroup should
be 'dashboard' and the name should be identical as WSGIDaemonProcess'
name. It is required to set /var/run/wsgi as WSGISocketPrefix.

[1] http://modwsgi.readthedocs.org/en/latest/configuration-directives/WSGIDaemonProcess.html

Change-Id: I9aca382798c7ab37e267c9988b3947e1b3780712

deleted_lines: $wsgi_user = 'apache' $wsgi_group = 'apache'

commit_message:
BP mistral-actions-design (switch to new design)

* Refactored action_factory.py (adhoc actions into a separate method)
* Fixed task db model (service_spec -> action_spec)
* Fixed workbook model (tasks, actions, Service -> Namespace)
* Fixed all tests related to DSL syntax changes

TODO:
* Fix all samples in mistral-extra
* Action plugin architecture

Change-Id: Iac6317dde894f17c81332a8c9a2397b70448f6b2

commit_message:
BP mistral-actions-design (ad-hoc actions in factory)

* Fixing action factory to create ad-hoc actions if needed
* More tests for action factory

TODO:
* Refactoring executor to use new action infrastructure
* Remove old action infrastructure
* Action plugin architecture

Partially implements: blueprint mistral-actions-design

Change-Id: I69946989226a1c05ed089acccb7e10a6516cf966

added_lines: DB_TASK_ADHOC = { 'task_spec': { 'name': 'my_task', 'action': 'my_namespace.my_action' }, 'action_spec': { 'name': 'my_action', 'namespace': 'my_namespace', 'class': 'std.echo', 'base-parameters': { 'output': '{$.first} and {$.second}' }, 'parameters': ['first', 'second'], 'output': { 'res': '{$.base_output}' } }, 'name': 'my_task', 'workbook_name': 'my_workbook', 'execution_id': '123', 'id': '123', 'tags': ['deployment', 'test'], 'parameters': { 'first': 'Tango', 'second': 'Cash' } } def test_adhoc_echo_action(self): db_task = DB_TASK_ADHOC.copy() action_spec = db_task['action_spec'] # With dic-like output formatter. action = a_f.create_action(db_task) self.assertDictEqual({'res': 'Tango and Cash'}, action.run()) # With list-like output formatter. action_spec['output'] = ['$.base_output', '$.base_output'] action = a_f.create_action(db_task) self.assertListEqual(['Tango and Cash', 'Tango and Cash'], action.run()) # With single-object output formatter. action_spec['output'] = "'{$.base_output}' is a cool movie!" action = a_f.create_action(db_task) self.assertEqual("'Tango and Cash' is a cool movie!", action.run())

added_lines: 'use strict'; module.exports = function(grunt) { var _ = require('lodash-node'); grunt.registerTask('i18n-vk', 'Search for missing keys from different locales in translation.json', function(task, param) { if (task == 'validate') { startValidationTask(param); } function startValidationTask(param) { var baseLocale = 'en-US'; var translations = grunt.file.readJSON('static/i18n/translation.json'); var existingLocales = _.keys(translations); var locales = param ? param.split(',') : existingLocales; var processedTranslations = {}; function processTranslations(translations) { function processPiece(base, piece) { return _.map(piece, function(value, key) { var localBase = base ? base + '.' + key : key; return _.isPlainObject(value) ? processPiece(localBase, value) : localBase; }); } return _.uniq(_.flatten(processPiece(null, translations.translation))).sort(); } _.each(locales, function(locale) { processedTranslations[locale] = processTranslations(translations[locale]); }); function compareLocales(locale1, locale2) { return _.without.apply(null, [processedTranslations[locale1]].concat(processedTranslations[locale2])); } _.each(_.without(locales, baseLocale), function(locale) { grunt.log.errorlns('The list of keys present in %s but absent in %s:', baseLocale, locale); grunt.log.writeln(compareLocales(baseLocale, locale).join('\n')); grunt.log.errorlns('The list of keys missing in %s:', baseLocale); grunt.log.writeln(compareLocales(locale, baseLocale).join('\n')); }); } }); };

commit_message:
move read_blob_file_contents to utils

Thinking ahead, a few other upcoming keystone features could
benefit from reading contents from a file. Thus, moving the
function from policy to utils.

Change-Id: I713ab0e5a00c949ad996daf83b775a7c19044888
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/77/84477/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def read_blob_file_contents(blob_file): with open(blob_file) as file: blob = file.read().strip() return blob

Spec for bp/message-in-update-notifications

blueprint message-in-update-notifications

Change-Id: I9c75a2feaeb7be0f079b8377932f668aa8b011c1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/26/84526/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Allow DB migration backports to Icehouse ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/message-in-update-notifications Add a human-readable message to compute instance update notifications. This will make it easier for external notification consumers to deduce the purpose of the update. Problem description =================== Nova emits a number of instance update notifications for various state changes and VM spawning steps. It can be difficult to reconstruct the purpose of the update from the message paylaod. Proposed change =============== Allow for extra fields in the compute.instance.update payload, including 'message' Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- Additional field(s) in payload Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Minimal Other deployer impact --------------------- Notification consumers must be able to cope with extra payload fields. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: belliott Work Items ---------- * Add extra fields to notification * Update virtapi to take extra_notification_info Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests Documentation Impact ==================== * 'message' field added to compute.instance.update notif References ========== None

commit_message:
fix wrong location of report_interval

report_interval is a config in section agent, not section DEFAULT.
It is used by the agents to scheduly report state, and not used by
neutron-server. Missing this config on agent side, leads to flapping
alive status of neutron agents. Therefore report_interval is moved
from class neutron::server to class neutron

Change-Id: I4fa84dabcba8465b297f6dc0eefa1d02a98eafca

subject: network_info cache should be cleared before being rescheduled
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-01 23:20:57.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/network/test_neutronv2.py', 'nova/network/neutronv2/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/4f262692cef46f2a7f78f3491c31bd5bf245de00', 'message': "network_info cache should be cleared before being rescheduled

If an instance fails to boot due to a non-networking error the instance
then gets rescheduled and launched on another compute node. In these cases
deallocate_for_instance() is called which deletes the network ports
allocated though the info_cache for the instance is never cleared. This patch
adds a call to update_instance_cache_with_nw_info() which causes the cache
to get cleared out. Note: the cache is only cleared if the instance hasn't
been marked for deletion. This is due to how instance_info_cache_update()
is implemented.

Change-Id: If967884c9a6276f5949a7a04b597cedcce12ba09
Closes-bug: #1285158
(cherry picked from commit 3538a9cd06e1e46ec5698edf4018c8d3075b619b)
"}]
commit_message:
network_info cache should be cleared before being rescheduled

If an instance fails to boot due to a non-networking error the instance
then gets rescheduled and launched on another compute node. In these cases
deallocate_for_instance() is called which deletes the network ports
allocated though the info_cache for the instance is never cleared. This patch
adds a call to update_instance_cache_with_nw_info() which causes the cache
to get cleared out. Note: the cache is only cleared if the instance hasn't
been marked for deletion. This is due to how instance_info_cache_update()
is implemented.

Change-Id: If967884c9a6276f5949a7a04b597cedcce12ba09
Closes-bug: #1285158
(cherry picked from commit 3538a9cd06e1e46ec5698edf4018c8d3075b619b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/84583/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(arosen): This clears out the network_cache only if the instance # hasn't already been deleted. This is needed when an instance fails to # launch and is rescheduled onto another compute node. If the instance # has already been deleted this call does nothing. update_instance_info_cache(self, context, instance, network_model.NetworkInfo([]))

commit_message:
Fixed vpnaas agent for RedHat systems

The package vpnaas package was not installed by default for RedHat
systems, and the service had the incorrect name. This patch
installs the package and sets the correct service name.

Backport to stable/havana

Change-Id: Id54dfbcb918d7d9ba110eb238858162c5cc0380e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-neutron refs/changes/60/86660/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: $vpnaas_agent_package = false $vpnaas_agent_service = 'neutron-vpnaas-agent'

commit_message:
Update ensure()/reconnect() to catch MessagingError

The error handling code that gets connections reset if necessary
caught ConnectionError. It really needs to catch MessagingError,
which ConnectionError inherits from. There are other types of
MessagingErrors that may occur, such as InternalError, and they need
to cause the connection to reset, as well.

This fix has already been merged into oslo.messaging.

Closes-bug: #1303890
Change-Id: Ic5082b74a362ded8b35cbc75cf178fe6e0db62d0
(cherry picked from commit 234f64d608266f43d8856ff98c89ceba6699d752)
(cherry picked from commit fae88f6805f6a16a60c23da67ce06cc0c78a706d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/32/87032/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: except qpid_exceptions.ConnectionError: except qpid_exceptions.ConnectionError as e: qpid_exceptions.ConnectionError) as e:

commit_message:
Add known_stores option in class glance::api

In glance-api, if you use known_stores's default value and didn't use
all of the stores listed in known_stores, then glance-api service will
throw an error to point out which store missing, see more description
in related bug link.
This patchset adds known_stores option in glance::api, so that users
can configure it by their own needs.

Change-Id: If08254f419d182b82cc50137383985834f40a6fd
Closes-bug: #1259403

commit_message:
add template_file parameter to specify catalog

this lets you set the catalog to use when catalog_type
is set to 'template'.
Also added some tests according to catalog settings.

Change-Id: I48c3b903ceafe94f2ec31b49d617e5a9951de7f9

deleted_lines: value => '/etc/keystone/default_catalog.templates'; value => ' keystone.catalog.backends.sql.Catalog'

commit_message:
Add fping utility path to nova.conf

fping package introduced by Ibdc7479a9038321e4fc3953774a6f3e1dac90530 .
But there is difference between Nova's default fping path and Ubuntu
package path. So we can't still use os-fping API in Ubuntu. This commit

commit_message:
Remove variable part of agent dict to fix AgentManagementTest

Agents may vary their configuration while API tests blindly
compare agent dicts. Need to pop items that may change.

Change-Id: I150f4e9f2e79f6e20f18dee69cf061c68a5bed68

commit_message:
Fix consoleauth/spice duplicates on RH (#1278452)

On RedHat, consoleauth and spicehtml5proxy packages has the same name
( openstack-nova-console ), so we have a duplicate resource (see: #1278452).
In this context we can't use ensure_package of stdlib because we loose
notify/names attributes.)

Closes-bug: #1278452

Change-Id: I0141ca0233aead072a06796759d211cf1b6dc657
(cherry picked from commit 31a282a883ca8d2450195829d4e995ece699a6a7)

commit_message:
Remove a DB query for get_ports_by_node()

This renames get_ports_by_node() to get_ports_by_node_id() and changes
the node_id argument to always need to be the integer ID. This removes
the need for get_ports_by_node() to query the DB for UUID -> ID
conversion.

By doing this, we can save a DB query in the cases where we already have
the Node integer ID.

This is needed to help set up the next patch to clean up calls to
get_node(). There's now a case in port API controller where we need
to lookup the Node by UUID just to get its ID to be passed into this
call. Until we implement the Node lazy-loading code, we fetch the
full Node, but this isn't any worse than before for this case, as
I'm just moving it from the DB layer. I've noted this with a FIXME
and it will be made more efficient in the future.

Change-Id: I9993c0c87794171fb971524ac5c30490b3e33716

deleted_lines: def get_ports_by_node(self, node_id, limit=None, marker=None, :param node_id: The id or uuid of a node.

commit_message:
Update ensure()/reconnect() to catch MessagingError

The error handling code that gets connections reset if necessary
caught ConnectionError. It really needs to catch MessagingError,
which ConnectionError inherits from. There are other types of
MessagingErrors that may occur, such as InternalError, and they need
to cause the connection to reset, as well.

This fix has already been merged into oslo.messaging.

Closes-bug: #1303890
Change-Id: Ic5082b74a362ded8b35cbc75cf178fe6e0db62d0
(cherry picked from commit 234f64d608266f43d8856ff98c89ceba6699d752)

commit_message:
Fix issues with DataFlow and HttpAction result

 * Fixed apply_context. if context exists and expression
   try to get access to unexisting key in context, there is
   no errors, YAQL returns null. We return expression itself now
 * Fixed HttpAction in case wrong result. We should raise
   exception to force changing task state to ERROR

Change-Id: I0eb76a7e1ae54cd2a32269b36cbbc95b352d54b0

commit_message:
don't pass uris to keystone.conf

The uris hash is only needed by the templated catalog so we don't need
to pass it into the keystone.conf template

Change-Id: I652cdb478414d996ba0e4414f33c4ec95cde5101

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.compute import base from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest import exceptions from tempest import test class ServerGroupNegativeTestJSON(base.BaseV2ComputeTest): @classmethod @test.safe_setup def setUpClass(cls): super(ServerGroupNegativeTestJSON, cls).setUpClass() cls.client = cls.servers_client cls.server_group_name = data_utils.rand_name('server-group') cls.policy = ['affinity'] cls.invalid_server_group = data_utils.rand_name('@#$%&') cls.invalid_policy = data_utils.rand_name('#@$%&') @test.attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_create_server_group_with_invalid_name_valid_policy(self): # Create server-group with invalid name and valid policy self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.client.create_server_group, self.invalid_server_group, self.policy) @test.attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_create_server_group_with_valid_name_invalid_policy(self): # Create server-group with valid name and invalid policy self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.client.create_server_group, self.server_group_name, self.invalid_policy) @test.attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_create_server_group_with_conflicting_policies(self): # Create server-group with conflicting policies policies = ['affinity', 'anti-affinity'] self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.client.create_server_group, self.server_group_name, policies) @test.attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_get_server_group_with_invalid_id(self): # Get the invalid server-group self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.get_server_group, self.invalid_server_group) @test.attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_delete_server_group_with_invalid_id(self): # Delete the invalid server-group self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.client.delete_server_group, self.invalid_server_group) class ServerGroupNegativeTestXML(ServerGroupNegativeTestJSON): _interface = 'xml'

commit_message:
Don't explode if we fail to unplug VIFs after a failed boot

Libvirt currently attempts to unplug VIFs after destroying an
instance, which can fail if the instance was never built
properly in the first place. This patch makes it ignore errors
when trying to tear down VIFs during that cleanup. Failure
in this case would block the deletion of the instance (which
should never happen) and any real failures aren't something
we could do anything about.

Closes-bug: #1306718

Change-Id: I84a4433c3959b8f14e0259be0aa51da1654006c8

commit_message:
Add warn Log in ComputeFilter if a service is disabled by hypervisor

Right now if the ComputeFilter encounters a disabled host,
it just logs it at debug level and skips it. If the host was automatically
disabled because of a connection fail, we should at least log that
as a warning in the scheduler
(like we do now for hosts that haven't checked in for a while)

Partial-Bug: #1258625

Change-Id: Ie15887e2af03add756345a789aeb2e0dd12faa05

When an image is created the location header returned is generated based

wrongly generated with that.  The osapi_glance_link_prefix config option

commit_message:
Use osapi_glance_link_prefix for image location header

When an image is created the location header returned is generated based
on the request url that nova-api receives.  If SSL termination happens
upstream the request url is an http request, and the location header is
wrongly generated with that.  The osapi_glance_link_prefix config option
is available for almost precisely this purpose, so let's use it.

Change-Id: I24e46ed8fc0763f9ddeec65e0d79590dd7b86bef
Closes-bug: 1298005

commit_message:
config-approach

Change-Id: I07709a5322545ef03fb30b5e472bd0e094fd486a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/25/87525/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: How will we write our nova.conf + other config files? My proposed approach is to write a new hp-config-templates element which includes os-apply-config/etc/nova.conf: {{hp-config.nova-conf}} Allowing us to use Heat templates like: Compute0: Type: OS::Server Metadata: hp-config: nova-conf: get_file: nova.conf get_file is a Heat function: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/heat/template_guide/hot_spec.html#get-file If this works, the benefits are collecting all the config files into one place (hp/ce/master of hp-heat-templates), being able to write nearly raw files and being able to update config arbitrarily via Heat. The main risk is that Heat/os-collect-config may not like us using kilobytes of metadata. Again, if this works, service teams should find it very easy to provide their configuration by 1) adding a template to hp-config-templates, 2) adding two lines to the CE Heat template, 3) providing the file. A significant detail is that hp-config-templates must supply an os-refresh-config script which runs os-apply-config at level 50. This should mean that it runs twice, enabling the inserted templates to be filled out. There's a risk here that if a non-HP file includes something which looks like a Mustache template (pretty unlikely I hope), that section may disappear causing confusion and errors. ----- Other options: Rob's approach is exemplified here: http://paste.openstack.org/show/VqKw97HHVdcQqhod6tkg/ It's ok as long for INI files if you don't mind swaddling your config (data.json is 25 lines compared to the 6 lines of output). Every new config file format means a new generic template. Last and least, Mustache can't nest arbitrarily so some formats will be artificially limited. I looked at file injection using the Heat Server resource's Personality section. This essentially uses Nova file injection. There are concerns over performance and whether this works with `heat stack-update`. We wouldn't have to run os-apply-config twice though.

commit_message:
Provide multiple levels for os-apply-config

The primary usecase for this is to allow a system integrator to
configure her system by supplying templates in a 99-os-apply-config
directory. Those templates will take precedence over ones supplied by
individual elements and the system integrator can bake in their own
values without having to actually use the templating system, apart from
per-instance values.

I've provided many levels rather than just one so that if required,
elements can overwrite each others' templates. I don't expect this will
be needed often though.

See etherpad:
  https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/tripleo-config-passthrough

Change-Id: I13be3abeda5f75f85cb1daf3a409588a2f9898fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/05/86305/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # This script will copy the templates to the appropriate location. # Templates in higher-numbered directories will overwrite those in # lower-numbered directories. # Note that the implementation relies on the detail that all elements # share one dir inside the chroot.set -o pipefail TEMPLATE_SOURCE_PREFIX=$(dirname $0)/.. for BN in {00..50}-os-apply-config \ os-config-applier \ os-apply-config \ {51..99}-os-apply-config; do TEMPLATE_SOURCE=${TEMPLATE_SOURCE_PREFIX}/${BN} if [[ -d "${TEMPLATE_SOURCE}" ]]; then rsync --exclude='.*.swp' -Cr $TEMPLATE_SOURCE/ $TEMPLATE_ROOT/ fi done
deleted_lines: # Note that this relies on the detail that all elements share one dir # inside the chroot. This will copy all the files that elements have # added to element/os-config-applier or element/os-apply-config into the # appropriate location.TEMPLATE_SOURCE=$(dirname $0)/../os-config-applier rsync --exclude='.*.swp' -Cr $TEMPLATE_SOURCE/ $TEMPLATE_ROOT/ TEMPLATE_SOURCE=$(dirname $0)/../os-apply-config rsync --exclude='.*.swp' -Cr $TEMPLATE_SOURCE/ $TEMPLATE_ROOT/

commit_message:
Linux native bonding for Advanced Network Configuration

Creating linux native bonding in a "transformation" section of network_schema.
Also creates configuration records for all slave interfaces.

blueprint linux-bonding
Change-Id: Ifc69aab96555ae34fe9c0f0fe0c2789d538c8bfc

added_lines: :provider => 'ovs', :br => { :name_of_resource => 'l23network::l2::bridge' }, :port => { :name_of_resource => 'l23network::l2::port' }, :bond => { :name_of_resource => 'l23network::l2::bond' }, :bond_lnx => { :name_of_resource => 'l23network::l3::ifconfig' }, :patch => { :name_of_resource => 'l23network::l2::patch' }, :ifconfig => { :name_of_resource => 'l23network::l3::ifconfig' } if t[:provider] == 'lnx' if ! ifconfig_order.index(t[:name].to_sym()) ifconfig_order.insert(-1, t[:name].to_sym()) end end if action == :bond and t[:provider] == 'lnx' # Add Linux_bond-specific parameters to the ifconfig res_name = :bond_lnx e_name = t[:name].to_sym if ! endpoints[e_name] endpoints[e_name] = create_endpoint() end endpoints[e_name][:properties] ||= {} endpoints[e_name][:properties][:bond_properties] = Hash[t[:properties].map{|k,v| [k.to_s,v]}] born_ports.insert(-1, e_name) t[:interfaces].each{ |iface| if ! endpoints[iface.to_sym] endpoints[iface.to_sym] = create_endpoint() end endpoints[iface.to_sym][:properties] ||= {} endpoints[iface.to_sym][:properties][:bond_master] = t[:name].to_s } else # normal OVS transformation resource = res_factory[action][:resource] p_resource = Puppet::Parser::Resource.new( res_factory[action][:name_of_resource], trans[:name], :scope => self, :source => resource ) # setup trunks and vlan_splinters for phys.NIC if (action == :port) and config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym] and # does adding phys.interface? config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2] and # does this interface have L2 section config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:trunks] and # does this interface have TRUNKS section config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:trunks].is_a?(Array) and config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:trunks].size() > 0 # does trunks section non empty? Puppet.debug("Configure trunks and vlan_splinters for #{trans[:name]} (value is '#{config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:vlan_splinters]}')") _do_trunks = true if config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:vlan_splinters] if config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:vlan_splinters] == 'on' elsif config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:vlan_splinters] == 'auto' sp_nics = lookupvar('l2_ovs_vlan_splinters_need_for') Puppet.debug("l2_ovs_vlan_splinters_need_for: #{sp_nics}") if sp_nics and sp_nics != :undefined and sp_nics.split(',').index(trans[:name].to_s) Puppet.debug("enable vlan_splinters for: #{trans[:name].to_s}") trans[:vlan_splinters] = true else trans[:vlan_splinters] = false if trans[:trunks] and trans[:trunks].size() >0 Puppet.debug("disable vlan_splinters for: #{trans[:name].to_s}. Trunks will be set to '#{trans[:trunks].join(',')}'") config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:trunks] = [] else Puppet.debug("disable vlan_splinters for: #{trans[:name].to_s}. Trunks for this interface also disabled.") _do_trunks = false end end # add trunks list to the interface if it given if _do_trunks _trunks = [0] + trans[:trunks] + config_hash[:interfaces][trans[:name].to_sym][:L2][:trunks] # zero for pass untagged traffic _trunks.sort!().uniq!() trans[:trunks] = _trunks end Puppet.debug("Configure trunks and vlan_splinters for #{trans[:name]} done.") end trans.select{|k,v| k != :action}.each do |k,v| p_resource.set_parameter(k,v) end p_resource.set_parameter(:require, [previous]) if previous resource.instantiate_resource(self, p_resource) compiler.add_resource(self, p_resource) transformation_success.insert(-1, "#{t[:action].strip()}(#{trans[:name]})") born_ports.insert(-1, trans[:name].to_sym()) if action != :patch previous = p_resource.to_s end

'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2014-04-01 17:27:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/ec021caa7482477c034edce9ac60ac45b6ea0995', 'message': "Add package providers and version lookup

This commits adds modified version of the
Puppet Package type. It includes code that
looks for package version in /etc/versions.yaml
file if the package is going to be installed instead
of just installing the first available version.

This lookup will be initiated only is you
pass :installed or :present to the package's
ensure property. Passing :latest, :absent
or explicit version string will cause
the default behaviour.

Lookups will be performed only for apt and
yum providers.

Yum and Apt providers in this patch are
hacked to support transactional rollbacks.
When the provider is updating the package from
one version to another it saves the diff of
packages to a file and if its ever asked to
install the previous version again the provider
takes the diff file and installs the previous
package versions and their dependencies.

Change-Id: I84e4b7540f9e72ceb2e1dee0762184d3e2b4356c
Implements: blueprint patch-openstack

pass :installed or :present to the package's
ensure property. Passing :latest, :absent
or explicit version string will cause
the default behaviour.

Lookups will be performed only for apt and
yum providers.

Yum and Apt providers in this patch are
hacked to support transactional rollbacks.
When the provider is updating the package from
one version to another it saves the diff of
packages to a file and if its ever asked to
install the previous version again the provider
takes the diff file and installs the previous
package versions and their dependencies.

Change-Id: I84e4b7540f9e72ceb2e1dee0762184d3e2b4356c
Implements: blueprint patch-openstack
"}]
commit_message:
Add package providers and version lookup

This commits adds modified version of the
Puppet Package type. It includes code that
looks for package version in /etc/versions.yaml
file if the package is going to be installed instead
of just installing the first available version.

This lookup will be initiated only is you
pass :installed or :present to the package's
ensure property. Passing :latest, :absent
or explicit version string will cause
the default behaviour.

Lookups will be performed only for apt and
yum providers.

Yum and Apt providers in this patch are
hacked to support transactional rollbacks.
When the provider is updating the package from
one version to another it saves the diff of
packages to a file and if its ever asked to
install the previous version again the provider
takes the diff file and installs the previous
package versions and their dependencies.

Change-Id: I84e4b7540f9e72ceb2e1dee0762184d3e2b4356c
Implements: blueprint patch-openstack
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/89/83789/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: munge do |value| # don't lookup version if we are going to explicitly remove a package break value if [:absent, :purged, :held].include? value # don't lookup version if we have explicitly provided a version break value if value.is_a? String package_name = @resource.name versions_file = '/etc/versions.yaml' Puppet.debug "Looking up version for '#{package_name}' package" break value unless File.readable? versions_file require 'yaml' versions = YAML.load_file versions_file stringify_hash versions break value unless versions.is_a? Hash package_name = package_name.to_s unless package_name.is_a? String break value unless versions.key? package_name ver = versions[package_name].to_s Puppet.debug "Got version #{ver}" ver end # convert hash's keys to strings # @param hash [Hash] def stringify_hash(hash) hash.dup.each do |k, v| next if k.is_a? String hash.delete k hash.store k.to_s, v end end

commit_message:
Move notification point to a better place

Follow-up for I80f325c9be9c171c2dc8d5526570bf64f0f87c78
"notify calling process we are ready to serve"

Xavier Queralt found issue with sending readiness notification from inside
run_service: it returns premature OK in case of multiple service endpoints
in one systemd service like nova-api which by default provides osapi, ec2 and
metadata services.

Instead, send readiness notification before entering wait loop for each
Launcher type.

Change-Id: I69bf10f353f5fecaaf89e537c2d3c46b73e39d36
Implements: blueprint service-readiness

commit_message:
sizelimit: port to Python 3

In the tests, use bytes for the request body, since that is what is used by
webob in Python 3.

In RequestBodySizeLimiter.__call__(), do not compare NoneType to an integer: it
is forbidden in Python 3. Instead, properly handle the fact that
req.content_lenght might be None.

Change-Id: I179997789b9e2fcd3f3326e4d724e547c807f195

  scenario.
* It is an error to specify both 'times' and 'duration' in scenario
  config.
* Improved fixed time and fixed duration continuous unit tests
  to include timeout failure mode cases.

commit_message:
Split ContinuousScenarioRunner to constant and constant duration

* When 'type' in scenario config is 'constant', then
  use ConstantScenarioRunner.
* When 'type' in scenario config is 'constant_for_duration',
  then use ConstantForDurationScenarioRunner.
* Sample task configs renamed from 'continuous' to 'constant'.
* Renamed continous.py to constant.py.
* Error to specify 'continuous' for 'type' in scenario config.
* Error to specify 'times' and 'duration' in same config.
* Error to omit 'type' from scenario config.
* Error to omit 'duration' when 'type' is constant_for_duration.
* Improved unit tests to include timeout failure mode cases.

bp benchmark-split-continuous-runner
Change-Id: Idb83f5be538bce5740c7cb6211364caaf2d53b7d

"multiprocessing.pool.IMapIterator.next") def test_run_scenario_continuously_for_times_with_timeout(self, mock_next): times = 1 timeout = 1 args = {"a": 1} config = {"times": times, "active_users": active_users, "timeout": timeout} # timeout on first iteration of scenario mock_next.side_effect = multiprocessing.TimeoutError() runner_cls = continuous.FixedTimesContinuousScenarioRunner runner = runner_cls(mock.MagicMock(), self.fake_endpoints) results = runner._run_scenario(fakes.FakeScenario, "do_it", fakes.FakeUserContext({}).context, args, config) self.assertEqual(mock_next.call_count, times) self.assertEqual(len(results), times) self.assertSetEqual(set(results[0].keys()), set(['time', 'idle_time', 'error'])) class FixedDurationContinuousScenarioRunnerTestCase(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(FixedDurationContinuousScenarioRunnerTestCase, self).setUp() admin_keys = ["username", "password", "tenant_name", "auth_url"] endpoint_dicts = [dict(zip(admin_keys, admin_keys))] endpoint_dicts[0]["permission"] = consts.EndpointPermission.ADMIN self.fake_endpoints = endpoint_dicts def test_validate(self): config = { "type": "fixed_duration_continuous", "active_users": 1, "duration": 1.0, "timeout": 1 } continuous.FixedDurationContinuousScenarioRunner.validate(config) def test_validate_failed(self): config = {"type": "continuous", "a": 10} self.assertRaises(jsonschema.ValidationError, continuous. FixedDurationContinuousScenarioRunner.validate, config) @mock.patch("rally.benchmark.runners.continuous.time.time") @mock.patch("rally.benchmark.runners.continuous." "multiprocessing.pool.IMapIterator.next") def test_get_and_run_scenario_continuously_for_duration(self, mock_next, mock_time): duration = 60 active_users = 3 args = {"a": 1} config = {"duration": duration, "active_users": active_users, "timeout": 1} result = {"time": 1} # force two iterations to execute expected_times = 2 expected_results = [result for i in range(expected_times)] mock_time.side_effect = [0, 30, duration + 1] mock_next.return_value = result "fixed_duration_continuous") results = runner._run_scenario(fakes.FakeScenario, "do_it", fakes.FakeUserContext({}).context, args, config) self.assertEqual(mock_next.call_count, expected_times) self.assertEqual(results, expected_results) @mock.patch("rally.benchmark.runners.continuous.time.time") @mock.patch("rally.benchmark.runners.continuous." "multiprocessing.pool.IMapIterator.next") def test_run_scenario_continuously_for_duration_with_timeout(self, mock_next, mock_time): duration = 60 active_users = 3 args = {"a": 1} config = {"duration": duration, "active_users": active_users, "timeout": 1} # force one iteration to execute expected_times = 1 mock_time.side_effect = [0, duration + 1] mock_next.side_effect = multiprocessing.TimeoutError() runner_cls = continuous.FixedDurationContinuousScenarioRunner runner = runner_cls(mock.MagicMock(), self.fake_endpoints) results = runner._run_scenario(fakes.FakeScenario, "do_it", fakes.FakeUserContext({}).context, args, config) self.assertEqual(mock_next.call_count, expected_times) self.assertEqual(len(results), expected_times) self.assertSetEqual(set(results[0].keys()), set(['time', 'idle_time', 'error']))

commit_message:
ensure log_file is absent when using syslog

When using syslog, we don't need to write in keystone.log file, so
log_file param should be absent to avoid any write in the file.

Example: run keystone-manage db_sync will write in ~/keystone.log
instead of /var/log/syslog.

Closes-bug #1292619
Signed-off-by: Emilien Macchi <emilien.macchi@enovance.com>
Change-Id: I9b2613294625f3df27a70f45bd964688a425c88e
(cherry picked from commit 2f4c960a4b6970f3ba4bdf8949ae09f48884b327)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/80/87480/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*log_file*] # (optional) Where to log # Defaults to false # $log_file = false, 'DEFAULT/use_syslog': value => true; 'DEFAULT/syslog_log_facility': value => $log_facility; if $log_file { keystone_config { 'DEFAULT/log_file': value => $log_file; 'DEFAULT/log_dir': value => $log_dir; } } else { if $log_dir { keystone_config { 'DEFAULT/log_dir': value => $log_dir; 'DEFAULT/log_file': ensure => absent; } } else { keystone_config { 'DEFAULT/log_dir': ensure => absent; 'DEFAULT/log_file': ensure => absent; } } }
deleted_lines: # logging config if $log_dir { keystone_config { 'DEFAULT/log_dir': value => $log_dir; } } else { keystone_config { 'DEFAULT/log_dir': ensure => absent; } } 'DEFAULT/use_syslog': value => true; 'DEFAULT/syslog_log_facility': value => $log_facility;

This IP " "address is permanently associated with the instance until the instance is " "terminated. However, in addition to the fixed IP address, a floating IP " "address can also be attached to an instance. Unlike fixed IP addresses, " "floating IP addresses are able to have their associations modified at any " "time, regardless of the state of the instances involved."#: ./doc/user-guide/section_dashboard_access_and_security.xml41(title) msgid "Add a rule to the default security group" msgstr "" #: ./doc/user-guide/section_dashboard_access_and_security.xml42(para)"This procedure enables SSH and ICMP (ping) access to instances. commit_message:
Overwriting node_is_available in IronicDriver

Overwriting node_is_available so it call to
node.get from the ironic client.

Change-Id: If27048342349c6eb87291416d82f719001db6dac
Closes-Bug: #1299288
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/14/84214/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def node_is_available(self, nodename): return nodename in self.get_available_nodes()

commit_message:
Move some template validation to Template class

This patch moves some template validation code to the Template class'
validate() method which has been introduced in change
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/83758 .

Going forward, this should make it easy to perform specific
validtion in Template sub-classes (HOT, CFN).

Change-Id: Iaf86f48d462231a7aa51adb642ea8920f9f43892
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/84/83984/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # validate overall template err = tmpl.validate() if err: return err # validate resource classes for res in tmpl_resources.values(): # validate parameters
deleted_lines: # validate overall template (top-level structure) tmpl.validate() if not tmpl_resources: return {'Error': 'At least one Resources member must be defined.'} for res in tmpl_resources.values(): try: if not res.get('Type'): return {'Error': 'Every Resource object must ' 'contain a Type member.'} except AttributeError: type_res = type(res) if isinstance(res, unicode): type_res = "string" return {'Error': 'Resources must contain Resource. ' 'Found a [%s] instead' % type_res}

commit_message:
Removed building shotgun package

This packaged is moved into external repository
https://github.com/kozhukalov/shotgun.git and at the
moment it is available on pypi.python.org

commit_message:
Added lvm partitioner

Added lvm partitioner. This commit supports
pvcreate, pvremove, pvdisplay actions. Other
lvm actions will be a part of futher commits.

Change-Id: I1d7f1cc50e3ee50fd5f7ea2d8997189194e7b563

commit_message:
Add CRUD operations for Federation Mapping Rules.

Add relevant methods for adding, updating, listing, getting, and deleting
Mapping objects.

Change-Id: I26a3822d9e341b9ddec10ecb8590432554837dce
Implements: blueprint federation-crud-operations
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/42/83742/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from keystoneclient import base class Mapping(base.Resource): """Mapping attributes container. Attributes: * ``id``: mapping id, """ pass class MappingManager(base.CrudManager): """Manager class for manipulating Identity Providers.""" resource_class = Mapping collection_key = 'mappings' key = 'mapping' base_url = 'OS-FEDERATION' def _put(self, **kwargs): url = self.build_url(dict_args_in_out=kwargs) body = {self.key: kwargs} return self._update(url, body=body, response_key=self.key, method='PUT') def create(self, mapping=None, rules=[], **kwargs): return self._put( mapping_id=base.getid(mapping), rules=rules, **kwargs) def get(self, mapping, **kwargs): return super(MappingManager, self).get( mapping_id=base.getid(mapping), **kwargs) def list(self, **kwargs): pass def update(self, mapping, rules=[], **kwargs): return super(MappingManager, self).update( mapping_id=base.getid(mapping), rules=rules, **kwargs) def delete(self, mapping): return super(MappingManager, self).delete( mapping_id=base.getid(mapping))

commit_message:
Fixing of confusing user names in fig 1.3

Replacement of figure 'cloud_dash_user_list' in user-admin-guide
in order to clarify users assignations.

commit_message:
Heat verification: provide a test template

Update the heat verification section of the install guide to use a
simple test template, with data from the install guide as environment
for the stack. This should make the testing easier for users not
familiar with heat.

Change-Id: I96b2af101972b2ac5ebc394e4e507bcf0663596a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/73/87373/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat_template_version: 2013-05-23 description: Test Template parameters: ImageID: type: string description: Image use to boot a server NetID: type: string description: Network ID for the server SubNetID: type: string description: Subnet ID for the server resources: server1: type: OS::Nova::Server properties: name: "Test server" image: { get_param: ImageID } flavor: "m1.tiny" networks: - port: { get_resource: server1_port } server1_port: type: OS::Neutron::Port properties: network_id: { get_param: NetID } fixed_ips: - subnet_id: { get_param: SubNetID } outputs: server1_private_ip: description: IP address of the server in the private network value: { get_attr: [ server1, first_address ] }

commit_message:
nova notifications: use admin tenant name

Using ID in configuration files is difficult to maintain when installing
OpenStack.
In some cases, it's possible that the ID could change for some reasons
and using names is usually the choice of most of OpenStack projects.
This patch aims to use admin tenant name and to get the tenant ID from
keystone API directly.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Idd1cf2e943f8d7d8dea23fb19b53d693adea84cb
Closes-bug: 1302814

commit_message:
fix import for default clients in clients.py

All default clients will be imported in clients.py even
if the services are disabled in tempest.conf. That will
cause import error when run tests. This patch moves the
import statements into relevant functions.

Closes-Bug: #1307323

Change-Id: I1260cceb2821400eb42959cb701e40ae449dd452

commit_message:
Handle default AZ in AvailabilityZoneFilter correctly

In case the AZ is not specified in CLI the default AZ should be used.
Instead the AvailabilityZoneFilter doesn't filter any host.

Change-Id: If4a24a70b34cddcf26d33e3b49dede59b797fbf0
Closes-Bug: #1306602
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/87247/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update from tables to list structure in Cloud Admin Guide

Updated 'Basic Load-Balancer-as-a-Service Operations'and 'Provider extension API operations' sections to be a list instead of a table.

Partial bug: #1290447

Change-Id: I2ce247cc0893e9d499c9452ba3c9cb897beb0ed9

commit_message:
Use uuid instead of uuidutils

Update context from Oslo.
No longer import uuidutils from Oslo.
Droping the dependency would help deprecating/removing uuidutils
in the future.
This patch replaces uuidutils.generate_uuid() with
str(uuid.uuid4()).

Change-Id: Ibbf8d9907e59ca41e3e50169342db60dae940a12
Related-Bug: #1253497
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/60/76160/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid return 'req-%s' % str(uuid.uuid4())
deleted_lines: from openstack_dashboard.openstack.common import uuidutils return 'req-%s' % uuidutils.generate_uuid()
